title: Statesmanship has become too rare in Congress
author: LARRY HOGAN
content:
Statesmanship has become too rare in Congress

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY HOGAN | Section: Columns 
 
 721
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This week marks seven years since Sen. John McCain's (R-Ariz.) historic vote to save Obamacare. I will never forget a phone call I had with him just moments before he gave the big thumbs down on the Senate floor. He was reaching out about a statement I had issued opposing the Republicans' effort to repeal Obamacare. He thanked me for putting people over party and confidentially let me know he was going to do the same.Although we shared the same concern that our health care system desperately needs commonsense reforms to lower costs, McCain and I both knew that the Republican bill to repeal Obamacare was irresponsible and would jeopardize the health care coverage for our citizens.
As McCain told me that day, his vote was about far more than just Obamacare. While he was courageously battling brain cancer, he wanted to send a message to his colleagues and the nation that the broken status quo in Washington could not continue. In a speech later that day, he appealed that the Senate was being weighed down by partisan dysfunction and was on the "decline."
Can anyone dispute that the problem has grown far worse since McCain spoke those words seven years ago? Our political discourse is spiraling into rabid tribalism, hatred and violence. Politicians in Washington care more about appealing to the loudest and angriest voices than actually delivering for the people they serve. They are "trying to find a way to win without help from across the aisle." Ultimately, the losers of all this partisan dysfunction are the American people.
It wasn't always this way.
As McCain said: "I've known and admired men and women in the Senate who played much more than a small role in our history, true statesmen, giants of American politics. They came from both parties and from various backgrounds."
Last week, I had the honor of attending a memorial service to remember one of those giants: Sen. Joe Lieberman (D-Conn.). Though they were on different sides of the aisle, Lieberman and McCain were true friends who both loved this country and worked together on countless issues for the good of the nation.
When my father Larry Hogan Sr. served in Congress, he would debate about real issues with his colleagues across the aisle then sit down and actually get things done. Fifty years ago this week, he put aside partisanship and answered the demands of his conscience to do what he thought was the right thing for the state and nation that he loved, becoming the first Republican to come out for the impeachment of President Nixon.
This type of statesmanship has become far too rare. Increasingly, principled leaders who care more about making the Senate work for their constituents than their Twitter accounts are heading for the exits. Instead of serving as "an important check on the powers of the Executive" and working together to advance commonsense solutions, politicians in the Senate toe the party line and perpetuate the broken status quo to advance their careers.
Every election cycle, partisans on both sides of the aisle tell the American people that the only answer is just to vote straight party line regardless of the character and experience of the candidates. And every election cycle, our politics becomes even more divisive and dysfunctional as a result.
The only way we can fix this mess is to elect independent leaders who are not beholden to the broken system. I don't need a job or another title. I am running to be a completely different kind of senator. As a key swing vote who has never hesitated to stand up to my party, both parties will have to earn my support.
Only Maryland can count on my vote. That independence will give me an outsized influence to stand up for what is right, put Maryland at the center of every deal, and help make the Senate work again for the people.
This isn't just the typical fight between Democrats and Republicans. It's more important than that. This is a fight for America's future, and that is a fight worth fighting. McCain knew the truth: "The success of the Senate is important to the continued success of America … That responsibility is more important than any of our personal interests or political affiliations."
Former Gov. Larry Hogan is the Republican nominee for the open U.S. Senate seat in Maryland. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on national political issues, specifically the state of Congress, partisanship, and statesmanship, with references to federal figures like Sen. John McCain and Joe Lieberman. While it mentions Maryland politics, the core discussion revolves around national political dynamics and Senate operations, aligning most closely with 'National News.'

title: Harris VP pick lauded by Dems, scorned by GOP
author: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service
content:
Harris VP pick lauded by Dems, scorned by GOP

 August 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 791
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Vice President Kamala Harris' choice of Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as her running mate Tuesday won praise from Maryland Democrats, who pointed to the governor's experience and approach to politics as key assets in the fall campaign.Maryland Republicans, with one notable exception, saw little to like in the final piece of the Democratic ticket that will face off against former President Donald Trump and his vice presidential choice, Ohio Sen. J.D. Vance.
Rep. Steny Hoyer (D-Maryland) said in a statement that Democrats and other voters should be excited for his friend Walz, whom he called an invaluable member of the House Democratic Caucus during his time in Congress.
"His plainspoken, common-sense approach to governing allowed him to deliver for veterans and Minnesotans," Hoyer said. "I know he will bring that same dedication and empathy to the vice presidency."
Walz served in the House from 2007 until January 2019, when he became Minnesota's governor. He was reelected in 2022.
Harris' decision on her running mate came hours after she officially became the Democratic Party's nominee for the presidency, clinching the vote of 99% of delegates in a virtual roll call. Walz and Harris are set to start a battleground state tour together this week, debuting Tuesday evening in Philadelphia.
Before his political career, Walz was a high school teacher, football coach and command sergeant major in the Army National Guard.
Maryland Gov. Wes Moore, highlighted fellow Democrat and veteran Walz's experience in the Army and his "proven track record of progress" in a Tuesday post on X, formerly Twitter.
"His incredible journey of service … isn't just a source of inspiration for future generations and evidence of his deep commitment to this country; it's also proof of his effectiveness as a leader who is going to generate wins not just for the Democratic Party in November, but for the entire country," Moore said.
"To the window ... to the Walz!!!" the Maryland Democratic Party tweeted, inviting Maryland residents to sign a card welcoming the governor to the campaign.
Rep. Jamie Raskin, D–Maryland, called Walz "a rock star to veterans, teachers, football players and common-sense Americans."
Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks, who is the Democratic candidate for the Senate, said in a statement that the Harris-Walz ticket presents a vision that stands "in diametric opposition" to the Trump-Vance ticket and is instead focused on protecting freedoms.
"I couldn't be more excited for Vice President Harris, for Maryland, and for our country in her decision of Gov. Tim Walz to be her running mate," Alsobrooks said.
Walz signed numerous pieces of LGBTQ+ protection legislation throughout his governorship including bills that protected gender-affirming care, banned book bans due to LGBTQ+ content and banned conversion therapy. The governor also signed bills protecting abortion in Minnesota and people who travel to Minnesota for the procedure.
Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, who served with the governor in Congress, said there was no better person to serve alongside Harris.
"Tim has always put our country first," Van Hollen said in a statement. "I'm excited and ready to do everything I can to turn out the vote and elect President Harris and Vice President Walz — a brighter future for all Americans and our democracy depends on it."
Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Maryland) kept his endorsement succinct, posting on X: "Harris-Walz. Strong. Experienced. Authentic. Unifying. Exciting! Can't wait to cast my ballot."
Rep. Andy Harris, the sole Republican in the Maryland congressional delegation, joined other party members in accusing Walz on X of being "pro-open border" and repeating the false claim that Harris is the "border czar."
"It is no surprise failed Border Czar Kamala Harris picked a running mate who is more pro-open border than she is," Andy Harris tweeted. "The same person who said he would invest in a ladder factory to defeat Trump's border wall is now vying to be VP."
Walz was critical of Trump's border wall proposal, supported a pathway to citizenship for Dreamers and signed a law that allows undocumented immigrants to get driver's licenses.
"The selection of Tim Walz as the Democrat candidate for vice president just confirms what we already knew: this is the most extreme, far-left ticket in modern American history," the Maryland Republican Party said in a statement.
However, Republican Senate candidate and former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan struck a different tone than his GOP counterparts. Hogan congratulated Walz on X and said the country needs more governors on the national level because "governors have to actually get stuff done."
"While we come from different parties, I have always appreciated his dedication to public service," Hogan said, acknowledging their past working together as governors.
Hogan is in an awkward place in his own party, whose national convention in Milwaukee he skipped last month. He has said he will not support Trump, even though the former president has endorsed him. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article covers the selection of a national political candidate (Tim Walz as VP pick) and reactions from national political figures, aligning with 'National News' as the primary topic. Local Government is a secondary consideration due to mentions of Maryland officials, but the core subject is national political developments.

title: Gov. Larry Hogan: A pragmatic difference maker
author: DARIN THACKER
content:
Gov. Larry Hogan: A pragmatic difference maker

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DARIN THACKER | Section: Columns 
 
 557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last year's Christmas break was memorable for me, and not just because of the special time with family.As someone who was raised in Lusby and currently works for a U.S. senator, I was motivated to encourage former Gov. Larry Hogan to seek Maryland's open seat in the U.S. Senate. I believe he's a generational leader whose service in the Senate would greatly benefit Maryland and the country, so I used my time off to write him a personal letter to make my appeal.
Gov. Hogan kindly responded by inviting me to meet with him a week later where I continued my pitch. It was ultimately the chronic dysfunction of the Senate, and specifically its failure in early February to strengthen our nation's border security and immigration laws, that drove him to run. But I'm grateful that a heartfelt letter helped trigger his consideration.
My Senate experience gives me confidence that Gov. Hogan would be very effective for Maryland and stand against the extremes of both parties, regardless of who holds the majority in the Senate or wins the White House.
Senators tend to fall into two camps: Partisan ideologues and pragmatic difference makers. Ideologues push their unrealistic, and oftentimes extreme, policy agendas. They take actions that cause constituents with diverse viewpoints to run to their corners, not solve problems. They almost always vote the party line and perpetuate division and gridlock. Their record of legislative achievements is thin.
Senators who are difference makers are the exact opposite. They are principled but practical. They seek bipartisan solutions and recognize that meaningful progress often comes in incremental steps. They acknowledge that members from both parties have good ideas. And they embrace the counsel of former President Barack Obama who said, "No one is exempt from the call to find common ground."
Larry Hogan is a proven difference maker. As governor Marylanders saw him work across the aisle to strengthen our economy and make our communities safer. He went to every corner of the state, worked with folks of every ethnicity and economic status and locked arms with local leaders from every party to get things done.
As a result he left office with a 77% approval rating — including a remarkable 81% approval rating among Democrats.
Further, Gov. Hogan would have an outsized influence among his Senate colleagues. Senate rules require 60 votes to pass most bills, which means Hogan would be at the center of finding bipartisan solutions on every major issue. He would also help defeat fringe legislation and judges from both parties. Contrary to the claims of Gov. Hogan's partisan opponents, Marylanders would be well served to have a senator who works from the political center to forge consensus and protect mainstream values.
In short, I believe Gov. Hogan's independent leadership is exactly what the Senate needs as it confronts the enormous challenges facing our country. He has a proven record of bipartisan achievement in Annapolis, and I have no doubt Gov. Hogan would continue to put country above party while representing Maryland across Route 50 in our nation's capital.
And if Marylanders do elect him in November, this year's Christmas break will end with something even more memorable for me than last's — Gov. Hogan taking the oath of office as U.S. senator.
Darin Thacker is chief of staff for U.S. Senator Steve Daines of Montana. He resides with his family in Accokeek, Maryland. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Gov. Larry Hogan's potential U.S. Senate run and his bipartisan political leadership, which relates to national political figures and federal governance. While it mentions Maryland, the core subject is his national political trajectory and Senate implications, aligning most closely with 'National News.'

title: Maryland Delegates represent at the Democratic National Convention
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Maryland Delegates represent at the Democratic National Convention

 August 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 531
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHICAGO — Delegates from the Eastern Shore joined thousands of Democrats in Chicago for the Democratic National Convention this week.At the convention, which ran from Aug. 19 to 22, delegates selected Kamala Harris as the party's nominee for president and Tim Walz as its nominee for vice president. The Democratic party also made key decisions about the party's political platform.
Jared Schablein, an Eastern Shore delegate and chair of Shore Progress, said he was more than happy to have Walz as the vice presidential candidate.
"The Eastern Shore delegation is excited to see rural representation on the Harris-Walz ticket with Coach Tim Walz," he said. "You know, people are excited for a new generation of leadership that is committed to protecting our freedoms and really investing in middle-class families."
Schablein was there as a delegate from Maryland's 1st Congressional District, which encompasses the Eastern Shore, as well as Harford and parts of Baltimore counties. He said it was important to support a candidate that focused on issues affecting the Eastern Shore, such as affordable housing, expanding healthcare access and raising the minimum wage.
"This ticket is focused on letting people make their own choices in life, whether that's their own healthcare choices, whether that is their own choice in who they love, their own choice on when and how to start a family," Schablein said. "This ticket is about freedom, and I'm excited to go back to the Eastern Shore."
Schablein said he was happy to represent the Eastern Shore and even brought a plush muskrat named Earl to help bring attention to the area.
Lillia Rose, a delegate from Maryland's 6th Congressional District, which encompasses Allegany, Garrett and Washington counties and parts of Frederick and Montgomery counties, also hoped to draw attention to rural communities during the convention.
Rose said she loved the chance to participate in the rural caucuses that were offered at the DNC. She said it was great to learn how similar communities are motivating voters in areas that typically lean red.
Rose said listening to climate change activists representing Appalachia was one of her favorite parts of the convention.
"I was also really excited to hear about climate justice," Rose said. "That's an issue we've always had and proportionately affected by natural resource extraction, and it can kind of feel hopeless at times. And being a young person, you know, it sounds crazy, but I'm not thinking about myself. I'm thinking about my little cousins and saying 'what can I do now?'"
Alongside climate justice, a key issue for Rose was rural women's healthcare accessibility.
"These rural issues, where healthcare accessibility can be a huge challenge, whether that's because of lack of transportation, or just distances," Rose said. "… It gives me a lot of hope that people are going to be able to live in the areas they live in, and receive the care they deserve, especially women's health care."
At the end of the convention, Schablein said it was a great experience and he is excited to bring what he learned back home.
"The big slogan from this convention has been that we respect our neighbors, to make their own decisions and we disagree with them, even if we wouldn't make those decisions ourselves," Schablein said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article covers Maryland delegates participating in the national Democratic National Convention, focusing on presidential/vice-presidential nominations and party platform decisions. title: 'Buffalo Soldier' killed in WWII returning home
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
'Buffalo Soldier' killed in WWII returning home

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After nearly 80 years, the remains of a Maryland native who was killed in action during World War II will be coming back home.U.S. Army Pfc. Lemuel Dent Jr. will be interred on Sept. 5 at Cheltenham Veterans Cemetery in Prince George's County. Johnson Funeral Services of White Plains will perform graveside services preceding the interment.
A native of Ironsides, an area on Route 6 in Charles County, Dent was assigned to Company L, 3rd Battalion, 366th Infantry Regiment, 92nd Infantry Division, known as the "Buffalo Soldiers" in the European Theater. The U.S. Army combat unit was made up for Black soldiers.
Dent was killed Feb. 8, 1945, at age 30, near the Cinquale Canal, north of Viareggio, Italy, when the tank he was aboard was struck by enemy fire while crossing the canal.
The tank was struck by enemy mortar, machine gun and artillery fire. His body was not recovered at the time, and the Germans never reported him a prisoner of war, the Defense POW/MIA Account Agency said in a release.
On May 5, 1945, the American Graves Registration Command, Army Quartermaster Corps, was the organization tasked with recovering missing American personnel in the European Theater. Investigators recovered a set of remains, designated as X-124 Castelfiorentino, from a gravesite approximately 2 miles west of Pietrasanta and 500 yards north of the Cinquale Canal, the accounting agency's release said.
The investigators initially associated the remains as possibly belonging to a soldier of the 92nd Infantry Division but did not have enough identifying data to make a positive identification. The remains were permanently interred at what is now Florence American Cemetery, the release said.
Dent was accounted for by the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency earlier this year on Feb. 2, after X-124's remains were exhumed in June 2022 from the Florence American Cemetery in Impruneta, Italy, for laboratory analysis and identification, U. S. Army Human Resources Command Public Affairs Office said in a release.
To identify Dent's remains, scientists used anthropological analysis. Additionally, scientists from the Armed Forces Medical Examiner System used mitochondrial DNA analysis, the accounting agency's release said.
The Past Conflict Repatriations Branch, under the Army Casualty and Mortuary Affairs Operations Division at the U.S. Army Human Resources Command in Fort Knox, Ky., plays a key role in the process of locating family members of missing soldiers from WWII and the Korean and Vietnam Wars.
The process begins with locating the family member most closely related to the missing soldier — known as the primary next of kin — followed by a request for family reference samples or DNA, which are used as a main source in identifying remains.
Once a soldier has been identified by the Armed Forces Medical Examiner, the Past Conflict Repatriations Branch notifies and briefs the family about the results of historical, forensic and DNA reports, benefits and the mortuary process including burial with full military honors.
Terrence Johnson of Johnson Funeral Services said that this is the first time that he has dealt with a WWII soldier who was killed in action.
Johnson was unsure if this was the first time a WWII soldier was reinterred in Charles County.
He said it was "hard to say" how attended the public funeral may be as Dent was survived by four sisters and five brothers, but the family members are "spread out."
Dent's name is recorded on the Tablets of the Missing at Florence American Cemetery, along with others still missing from WWII. A rosette will be placed next to his name to indicate he has been accounted for. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details the repatriation of a WWII soldier's remains after 80 years, highlighting historical military service, identification processes, and national military honors. While local elements are present, the core focus is on a significant historical event with national implications, aligning most strongly with 'National News.'

title: Who is better for Talbot County, Harris or Trump?
author: JIM BRUCE
content:
Who is better for Talbot County, Harris or Trump?

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM BRUCE | Section: Columns 
 
 1253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tuesday's presidential debate provides new information about how a Trump or Harris presidency would affect Talbot County. Buried among the barbs and points well-taken in the 90-minute debate are clues about what Talbot can expect, although the debate certainly did not address every way that the next White House will affect our county.Talbot County's economic future depends on who wins the presidency. In the debate Trump doubled down on his plan to impose large tariffs, 20% and more on imported products, particularly Chinese items (about 80% of Walmart's inventory comes from China). He ignores what economists say — foreign firms will raise their prices on their exports to us to offset these import tariffs, leaving American consumers, not the exporter, paying higher prices and prompting inflation.
Further, these tariffs will provoke retaliatory tariffs as happened in Trump's first presidency when our national soybean exports to China plummeted 75%. Talbot County has about 40,000 acres of soybean crops, more than any other cash crop. Note that Goldman Sachs just predicted that Trump's policies on tariffs and immigration would lead to an economic downturn, while the U.S. economy would grow if Harris is elected.
Although Maryland law strongly protects reproductive rights, which a state constitutional amendment on the ballot (Question 4) this fall would further strengthen, if Congress were to pass and the president sign a federal ban on abortions, it would preempt Maryland's protections. Trump said in the debate he does not support a federal law banning abortions, but when asked if he would pledge to veto such a ban, Trump dodged the question. The moderator asked Trump again, noting that J.D. Vance has said that Trump would veto a federal abortion ban. Trump dodged again explaining that Congress would never pass such a bill.
Trump took credit for the Supreme Court reversing Roe v. Wade and shifting the issue to the states. He explained that he acted because some states were allowing abortion in the ninth month and even beyond. "In other words, we'll execute the baby." This was too much even for the moderator who jumped in to say, "There is no state in this country, where it is legal to kill a baby after it is born."
In contrast, Harris was clear, "I absolutely support reinstating the protections of Roe v. Wade," and pledging that when Congress passes a bill codifying Roe v. Wade, "I will proudly sign it into law."
In 2022, 2,810 people in Talbot were listed as foreign-born, but we don't know how many "undocumented immigrants" live here. Trump distracted much of the immigration debate repeating unproven allegations that immigrants are eating our pet cats and dogs. Talbot's real risk is that Trump pledges to deport substantially more than 11 million "undocumented immigrants" using the national guard, local police, federal immigration officials, and if necessary, our military, going door to door.
This largest mass deportation in our history would cause bedlam in our county and certainly in our workplaces with many businesses having to close. Trump continues to demonize immigrants, insulting Talbot's growing Hispanic and other foreign-born populations and creating fear in our communities. The moderator asked Trump why he killed Congress' tough, bipartisan immigration bill that would have put thousands of additional agents on the border. Trump never answered the question. Harris supports this bill, accusing Trump of preferring to run on the immigration issue, but not solve it.
Health care is crucial for Talbot because our population is aging, and our largest employer is health care and social services. The debate focused on what will happen to the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), which is popular because of its coverage for pre-existing conditions. Harris stated her absolute support for maintaining and growing the program and private health care options as well.
When the moderator asked Trump why he initially opposed the program but now supports it, Trump responded that he decided to save the program and improve it. Pressed about whether he has a plan now to do that, Trump said, "I have concepts of a plan," about which we would be hearing more in the future. Kamala pointed out that for nine years the Republicans tried 60 times to kill the program, which survived by one vote from a Republican, the late Sen. John McCain. Republicans never presented an alternative plan.
Nearly 21,000 Marylanders are of Ukrainian extraction and far more of us, including in Talbot, sympathize with Ukraine. In the debate, Harris described her continuing efforts to help Ukraine defend itself, beginning before the Russian invasion. When the moderator asked Trump not once, but twice, if he believes that it is in the U.S. best interests for Ukraine to win this war, Trump said instead it is in our best interests to end the war by a settlement that he claims he could negotiate between Zelensky and Putin, even before Trump's inauguration.
Further, Trump claimed the war should never have started, suggesting falsely that Harris caused it because she was such a weak emissary sent to negotiate with Putin that he invaded Ukraine three days later. In fact, Harris had never met with Putin. Stoking fear and providing insight into his motivations, Trump pointed to Putin's nuclear weapons, adding, "And eventually, maybe he will use them." For 300 years, people of Talbot have learned we must stand up to tyrants like Putin.
With 600 miles of shoreline, Talbot County is especially vulnerable to the rising waters from climate change. In the debate, Harris reiterated her belief that climate change is real, we can and must address it. When Harris said that Trump had called it a hoax, Trump only responded with a disjointed reply on other subjects. (Note that the Republican platform unveiled in their convention has not a word on climate change.)
The difference in the two candidates' specific policy proposals presented in the debate is striking. Kamala Harris calls for a $50,000 tax deduction to help start up businesses. She wants a $6,000 tax credit for young families for the first year of a child's life. To help address affordable housing she seeks a $25,000 down payment assistance for first-time homebuyers, and to build 3 million new homes over four years. She pledges more negotiation with pharmaceuticals to drive down drug costs, such as the $35 cap on insulin prices.
Scouring the debate transcript, all I saw of Trump's policy proposals, other than generalizations (I will make American great again), were his pledge to reduce taxes, and to impose large tariffs on most foreign products. In her closing statement, Kamala lays out her policy vision in broad strokes. Trump spent his closing time attacking Harris' plans, labeling her the worst vice president in history, and darkly predicting we will wind up in a third world war.
To me the most telling clue to what our county and the rest of our country can expect from the next White House regards its character. History is replete with tragic figures whose regimes failed because they could not honestly self-appraise, accept criticism, learn from it, and alter course accordingly.
Throughout the debate we all heard Trump proclaim every aspect of his first presidency the best in history and that of Biden/Harris the worst. In a postscript to the debate, Trump declared, "We won the debate according to every poll — every single poll, I think."
His supporters tried to cover up this obvious falsehood by explaining that the moderators were biased, and even that Harris cheated using earbuds for outside coaching disguised as pearl earrings. Trump now refuses to debate Harris again.
If you care about Talbot County, vote for Kamala Harris. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes the impact of national presidential candidates' policies on a local county, focusing on economic, social, and political issues of national significance. While it mentions local implications, the core content revolves around national political debates, making 'National News' the primary topic.

title: Rep. Harris, local Republicans speak at Denton rally supporting Trump
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Rep. Harris, local Republicans speak at Denton rally supporting Trump

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Republican leaders and supporters gathered for a Caroline County rally Saturday in support of presidential candidate Donald Trump and Maryland Republicans running for office this November.The event, which took place at Caroline County 4-H Park, was organized by Caroline County Republican Women. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) was the featured speaker Saturday afternoon.
As he runs for his eighth consecutive term in the House of Representatives, Maryland's only Republican in Congress asked voters to support him as well as the entire Republican ticket. He emphasized a tight race in Congressional District 6, where Republican candidate Neil Parrott is vying to potentially join Harris as conservative representation in the House.
"We got a job to do. Because if President Trump is going to succeed, we need to have a House majority, so I'm going to ask for your vote," Harris said.
"Those of you who know people who live out in western Maryland, call them up and tell them to vote for Neil Parrott, because I'm tired of being the only Republican in the House delegation from Maryland, and we got a shot," he said.
Caroline County Republican Women member Joanne Smith helped organize Saturday's event. She said the group held a gathering back in 2020 as well. In her eyes, Trump is a fit for Caroline County voters.
"I think Trump represents our values," Smith said. "We're a very red area. Everybody in Caroline County that's elected is Republican."
"We desperately want to see a change in our government and Trump's our man," she added.
Much of Saturday's discussion centered on ensuring Republicans secure a Senate majority. Harris encouraged attendees to vote for former Gov. Larry Hogan as he runs for Maryland's open Senate seat against Democratic opponent Angela Alsobrooks.
Harris emphasized that without a Republican majority in the Senate and a Trump victory, conservative judges cannot be placed on the Supreme Court bench.
Adorned in a "Make America Great Again" baseball cap, Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) also asked voters to toe the party line..
"Vote straight down the ticket, Donald Trump, Larry Hogan, Andy Harris," Mautz said. "Whatever it is, whatever the qualm is, it doesn't matter. We need to get out, and we need to vote."
"This is war," he continued. "We're at a national crossroads right now, and we need to put all of our cards on the table."
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) attended Saturday's rally, as well as Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker.
Speaking to eventgoers, Hutchinson predicted that November's general election will play out similar to the 2016 vote, with Trump claiming swing states and the presidency. "We can't wait to see it happen again," he said.
The state delegate said in an interview with the Star Democrat that the economy is the number one reason for residents on the Shore to support Trump.
"We see with our rising food prices, gas prices, housing prices, it's affecting everybody here on the Shore," Hutchinson said. " … I see it within my district, how it's really affecting the middle-income and low-income families."
Smith and Harris both noted an increase in enthusiasm among local Republicans to win back the White House. "We want to get back to the Trump years," Harris said in an interview.
Denton resident Thomas Conneely Jr. attended Saturday's gathering and echoed that sentiment.
"I see that there's more energy," Conneely Jr. said. "But I also see an urgency that it's an emergency. That's what I see. I see people looking at it as, 'We have to.' If we don't, we're in deep trouble." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it includes local elements, the primary context is national political activity.

title: Clear choice for US senator
author: Staff Writer
content:
Clear choice for US senator

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 306
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Based on his duties and performance as Maryland's governor, Larry Hogan is the clear choice for U.S. senator.As governor, Mr. Hogan appointed some 80 judges. He was lauded in March 2022 in no less than the Washington Post for the selections he made and the process he used in assuring diverse and highly qualified candidates for both lower and appellate state courts. As head of the National Governor's Association during the pandemic, he was a very effective leader and spokesperson for the nation's governors, both Republican and Democratic. He worked effectively with leaders of all stripes, including two presidents.
He governed with the money he had, left the state with a surplus, and kept his pledges to Marylanders on taxes and abortion. He improved Maryland business climate rankings. He reacted to the disastrous defunding the police movement by refunding local police. He implemented a school choice program for lower income, underserved students. He left the state far better than he found it.
By contrast, it's hard to discern much about his opponent as Prince George's County executive that compares to Hogan's credentials unless you embrace identity politics. Her school system dwells near the bottom of most rankings. Hers was the last school system to reopen for in-person instruction in the pandemic. She reallocated funding for a proposed police training facility. Violent crime has increased. The current Prince George's state's attorney and Maryland attorney general both endorsed her opponent in the Democratic primary.
We know Mr. Hogan will be a fiercely independent and a reasoned voice in the Senate regardless of who is elected president and will bring people together to find common ground to benefit Maryland. On the other hand, Ms. Alsobrooks, given her continual fawning over the vice president as her mentor, will probably be a mere rubber stamp for Vice President Harris if elected.
EUGENE T. LAUER
Cambridge

title: Sept. 10 debate is history, but the hype goes on
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Sept. 10 debate is history, but the hype goes on

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 747
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first and perhaps only debate for the 2024 presidential general election that was held on September 10th is history.Throughout their long history these debates have always experienced pre-debate and post-debate disagreements.
After one of the first of three televised presidential debates in 1960, there was disagreement on the winner. A majority of voters who watched that debate on television responded in a post-debate survey that John F. Kennedy won. A majority of voters who listened to that debate on the radio responded in a post-debate survey that Nixon won.
Prior to the most recent debate, the Harris campaign adamantly refused to consider an offer from Fox News to host a debate, an offer strongly favored by the Trump campaign.
This year's on-again, off-again debate between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris sponsored by ABC did have a happy ending for many voters. They were happy when the pre-debate hype and the actual debate ended.
While the pre-debate hype and actual debate are over, there have been and will continue to be intense discussions about the Sept. 10 debate between the candidates and their most steadfast supporters.
Topics for the post-debate debates include, but are not limited to: who won, why they won, who lost, why they lost, the fairness of the moderators, the questions posed to each candidate by the moderators, incomplete candidate answers to certain questions from the moderators, the body language of the moderators, one moderator's recent acknowledgement that he chose to aggressively pursue fact-checking a number of Trump's answers during the debate, the validity of his fact-checking observations during the debate, the need for at least one more debate, and even the earrings worn by Kamala Harris during the debate.
Not surprisingly, in many cases, the varied answers to those post-debate debate questions are the result of the thinking on political messaging by communications guru Frank Luntz and two published works in the Washington Post on trust in the media. These observations have appeared in previous commentaries of mine, but all bear repeating here.
Luntz has observed: "It's not what you say or write, it is what people hear or read. You can have the best message in the world, but the person on the receiving end will always understand it through the prism of their own emotions, preconceptions, prejudices and preexisting beliefs."
No doubt the Trump campaign is fully aware of and will work hard to widely distribute the following recent and scathing observations by the Washington Post Editorial Board, and Washington Post columnist Philip Bloom that I referenced in a previous commentary.
The Post's editorial board cited a recent Post and Schar School of Policy and Government at George Mason University survey reporting only three in 10 residents of six of the most important states in this year's presidential election trust the media will fairly and accurately report political news. Bump recently wrote in the Post: "Americans simply don't trust the media, particularly when it comes to politics."
If and how those Washington Post observations may be viewed by voters remains to be seen.
The same is true on the news on a second assassination attempt on Donald Trump.
We know every political campaign will have unexpected opportunities and unexpected challenges. The question is always when and how will they play out.
For Donald Trump, an unexpected opportunity (now moot) was having President Joe Biden as his opponent when it was increasingly clear Biden was past his political prime.
For Donald Trump, an unexpected challenge was a debate where Kamala Harris exceeded expectations.
For Kamala Harris, an unexpected challenge was launching a presidential campaign on short notice.
For Kamala Harris, an unexpected opportunity was a debate where she branded herself as a viable presidential candidate.
Before the debate, some polls showed Trump leading Harris in all key battleground states.
After the debate, some polls polling in some of those battleground states showed Harris leading Trump in some of the key battleground states.
Neither of the polls projected enough state wins to clinch victory in the Electoral College.
The bottom line is the outcome of their Sept. 10 debate alone is not predictive of the November election outcome.
The voters who decide who prevails in November will not be significantly impacted by who won or who lost a 90-minute debate held in mid-September.
I expect most independent and undecided voters will vote based on their perceptions on which candidate cares most about their deepest concerns and who best articulates a positive and achievable vision for the future.
As always, one and only one candidate will ultimately enjoy a happy ending in the upcoming presidential election. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the 2024 presidential debate, a major national political event, with analysis of its impact on the election, media trust, and campaign strategies. While mentions of local newspaper publication exist, the content's core is national political news.

title: Our military veterans and heroes deserve respect
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
Our military veterans and heroes deserve respect

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 456
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There was a memorial recognition in Poland on Sept. 1 commemorating what is usually noted as the beginning of the Second World War when Nazi Germany invaded Poland in 1939. That long and terrible war would involve many members of my family.My father served in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific on an antiaircraft gunboat protecting larger ships from air attack. My father-in-law served in the U.S. Army infantry in Germany fighting in the Hürtgen forest and eventually being seriously wounded. My Uncle Ben was part of the 82nd Airborne Division jumping into France on D-Day. (He was also a great football coach, see Syracuse University 1960). I am very proud of all these people; they were all heroes.
Donald Trump, a former president of the United States, does not agree with me. In his own words he sees these people as "losers and suckers" not worthy of his respect or recognition.
Recently this same attitude was on full display when Donald Trump, invited by grieving families, organized a trip with cameras to Arlington Cemetery to visit Section 60 of that cemetery. Section 60 is reserved for fallen heroes from Iraq and Afghanistan. Arlington Cemetery specifically prohibits using the cemetery for political purposes.
An employee of the cemetery tried to prevent Trump and his staff from filming his political campaign video but was pushed aside. The U.S. Army has subsequently condemned Trump's actions and firmly defended the employee's actions. The employee has declined to press charges citing fear of harassment from Trump's supporters.
Mr. Trump recently denigrated those in our military who were awarded the Medal of Honor, our nation's highest military decoration. He described the Presidential Medal of Freedom, which he recently conferred on a wealthy campaign donor, as better because Medal of Honor winners are "in very bad shape because they've been hit so many times by bullets or they're dead." Our military says that a Medal of Honor winner may be saluted by any member of the military, regardless of rank. That is the respect due to those who wear this medal.
Then there is the issue of bone spurs. Mr Trump, at age 24, sought to avoid the Vietnam War. He was granted a draft classification that allowed him to avoid service because a doctor friend of his family certified that he suffered from disqualifying bone spurs. His family members have stated that no bone spurs were ever previously mentioned. Yet, he feels free to denigrate those who have served.
Any one of these actions makes you ask the question? Why does anyone want to support this man to be commander in chief of our armed forces? If you served our country in uniform, or you honor those who do, you should not vote for Donald Trump. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: How “blue” is Maryland? A closer look at the state’s voting history
author: DYLAN SHULMAN Capital News Service
content:
How “blue” is Maryland? A closer look at the state’s voting history

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DYLAN SHULMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 663
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 2024 election is Donald Trump's third bid for the U.S. presidency, having won in 2016 and lost in 2020. Maryland voted for the Democratic candidate in both cases, and its 10 electoral votes have been considered a given for the Democratic candidate in past general elections.As the 2024 general election nears, Capital News Service examined how Maryland has voted in presidential elections over the past 50 years.
"Maryland as a whole has high levels of education, which is one of the things—but only one of the things—that helps to account for its commitment to the Democrats," said Matthew Crenson, professor emeritus at Johns Hopkins University's political science department.
Other factors Crenson mentioned were that Black voters make up around 30% of Maryland's electorate, as well as large numbers of the Latino community, although the political leanings of the latter demographic are currently in flux.
Current Maryland opinion polls for the 2024 election have Harris ahead of Trump by a significant margin, par for the course in a state that has voted consistently blue for eight presidential elections. According to data from the Maryland State Board of Elections, Maryland voters have chosen only three Republican candidates since the 1960s: Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush.
In 1972, Nixon was an incumbent president who won re-election in a landslide victory, the largest popular vote margin in United States history. Reagan's 1984 victory was another case where the incumbent was an extremely popular candidate. In the following election, Bush narrowly won 51% of the Maryland popular vote.
It's generally agreed that the 2024 election's swing states are Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin; some include North Carolina in the list as well.
Are there "swing" counties in Maryland?Three counties switched sides between the last two elections: Frederick, Kent and Talbot voted for Trump in 2016, but Biden won in those three counties in 2020.
Kent could qualify as a swing county. Voters there chose the Democratic candidate three times out of the last nine elections, and the voting margins were typically small: in four elections, merely a fraction of a percentage point decided the county's popular vote. Kent is also the state's least populous county, with about 19,000 residents, according to 2020 U.S. census data.
"The balance of politics within a small population can change radically with relatively small changes in the population itself," Crenson explained.
Biden won Frederick County by about 10 percentage points in 2020. The three previous general elections in the county were close, with the Republican candidate winning in each case by less than four percentage points. Crenson said that Frederick County is becoming more politically divided as it becomes "a suburb of Washington."
"The result is that federal employees, most of whom vote Democratic, are beginning to populate Frederick County and taking over its electorate," Crenson said.
In fact, the voting habits along the entire I-95 corridor are subject to influence from the nation's capital, Crenson said.
"Government employees tend to have rather high levels of education and recently—that is, within the last 10 or 15 years—people with college degrees have been gravitating toward the Democratic Party," he said.
Maryland voter turnout—the percentage of registered voters who cast a ballot—also took a dip from 74% in 2012 to about 72% in 2016. A change in voter turnout under five percentage points is typical, but 2016 was the lowest voter turnout since 1996, the general election between Democrat Bill Clinton and Republican Bob Dole.
"Neither of the two candidates electrified Maryland," Crenson said.
The 2024 election will be the first general election after the COVID-19 pandemic. For the last election, which took place at the onset of the pandemic, the Maryland State Board of Elections restricted poll voting and encouraged voters to request and complete mail-in ballots, which accounted for a majority of all Maryland ballots.
The results of the 2024 election will establish whether many Marylanders continue to vote by mail or return to the polls. Crenson predicts that mail-in ballots will likely continue to be the avenue for many voters. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes Maryland's voting patterns in national elections, focusing on presidential elections, political trends, and demographic influences. While it includes local elements, the primary context is national political history and election dynamics.

title: Misleading statements and falsehoods
author: Staff Writer
content:
Misleading statements and falsehoods

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 393
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ms. Wieland's recent letter, which you labeled as, "We need strong leadership," was not long, but contained a huge number misleading statements and falsehoods. In that regard, it was impressive.She opens the letter asking if anyone other than her thinks the White House is devoid of leadership. Clearly this a joke. She should have put "LOL" after the question. Tens of millions of Trump supporters agree with her. Fortunately for America, more tens of millions don't agree. Trump has never won the popular vote and won't in the election.
Ms. Wieland then goes on to cite a series of alternative facts that are mostly not true. Kamala never said defund the police, never said she wants to give "illegals" all they want, never said she does not like Israel, never said she's going to take away Ms. Wieland's sacred guns. Here's a joke. How do you label someone who writes untruths? A Republican. (LOL)
Her closing wish is most ironic. She says she hopes Putin does not read her letter, so he does not learn what a mess America is in. Duh? This is like me saying, "I hope no one reads this, but Trump has romantic feelings for Putin." LOL. That's a joke because he only wrote love letters to the dictator of North Korea.
Finally, she calls for "strong leadership." Trump only thinks dictators are strong. Recently he said Putin is "at the top of his game." China is strong under a dictator Trump said he envies. The weak, according to Trump, are the United States military that are "suckers and losers" for defending America. All women are weak and liars, and they need him as a "protector" to make them happy. Jews are weak and may cost him the election. Immigrants are weak. People of color are weak and only work in "Black jobs." Christians who promote the love of Christ are weak. (In contrast to Christian Nationalists who promote hate and power.)
"Hey, Putin, listen up," Trump also says America is weak.
Trump is a coward. He is a bully, and bullies are cowards. His daddy got him out of service during Vietnam. All the sane military flag officers that served under him have written books about how stupid, reckless and cowardly he is.
Don't vote for Trump for strong leadership. Vote for Trump if you want a stupid coward as our dictator.
MICHAEL DAVIS
Easton

title: Consider the party platforms
author: Staff Writer
content:
Consider the party platforms

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Rather than deciding on one individual versus another, voters might instead consider party platforms and party methods of governing.One party tends to attract those engaged in commercial endeavors that must earn a profit. The other is dominated by those inside mostly non-profit entities whose funding is essentially unearned. These include university academics and their students, social cause activists, information technology groups and media providers. This party believes there are grand ideas for addressing real or imaginary problems.
In view of these distinctions, the two parties are motivated toward different ends. One party seeks a government that promotes free enterprise with only necessary regulations. The other is motivated to gain control of the government in order to implement grand ideas.
It seems that one party supports classical Constitutional freedom while the other seeks to impose a new system that circumvents Constitutional strictures. The 2024 Democratic Party platform states that "America is an idea."
"We must right the wrongs in our democracy, redress the systemic injustices that have long plagued our society, throw open the doors of opportunity for all Americans, and reinvent our institutions at home and our leadership abroad. We do not simply aspire to return our country to where we were four years ago. We know we must be bolder and more ambitious."
The 2024 Republican Party platform states "We will be a Nation based on Truth, Justice, and Common Sense."
To enter military service I took an oath to support and defend the Constitution. Voting for the Democratic Party platform would violate that oath.
PAYNE KILBOURN
Neavitt 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Big surprise'?: Anti-war vote could be a wild card in razor-thin Trump-Harris race
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
'Big surprise'?: Anti-war vote could be a wild card in razor-thin Trump-Harris race

 October 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News | Section: News 
 
 1590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Could anti-war voters (including Muslims and Arab-American Christians) upset with U.S. support for Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas potentially tip the 2024 election away from Vice President Kamala Harris in favor of former President Donald Trump?In 2020, President Joe Biden won 69% of the Muslim vote, compared to Trump's 17%, according to Council on American Islamic Relations (CAIR). Exit polls by the Associated Press in 2020 gave Biden 64% of the Muslim vote versus 35% for Trump.
Times have changed.
The Biden-Harris administration's military and diplomatic support for Israel's war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7, 2023, attacks and ongoing conflict with Hezbollah in Lebanon have eroded Arab-American and Muslim support for Harris' White House bid.
More than 43,000 people have died in Gaza since the start of the war more than a year ago, when Hamas killed 1,200 Israelis and took more than 250 hostages. More than 100 of those Israeli hostages (including a handful with dual American citizenship) are still being held by Hamas and other Islamic militants.
Israel's continued siege and bombings inside Gaza have killed more than 20,000 women and children, according to the United Nations, citing Palestinian estimates.
A worst-case scenario for Harris is that Muslim voters, Arab American Christians and other anti-war voters (including younger voters) back the Green Party's Jill Stein (who opposes the war and U.S. backing of Israel), Trump or sit out the election, which could potentially tilt the razor-thin election in battlegrounds including Michigan, Wisconsin and North Carolina.
SEISMIC SHIFT?A national poll released last month by the Arab American Institute found Arab Americans shifting away from Democrats and Harris.
The group said in the past Arab Americans voted for Democrats by a roughly 2-to-1 margin.
The October poll found Trump leading Harris among Arab Americans 42% to 41%, with 12% backing a third-party candidate such as Stein or Cornel West, who also opposes the Gaza war.
Harris is polling 18 percentage points below Biden's 2020 standing with Arab Americans, according to the poll.
"In our 30 years of polling Arab American voters, we have not witnessed anything like the role that the war on Gaza is having on voter behavior," said James Zogby, president of the Arab American Institute, in a statement, pointing out 81% of Arab Americans view the Israel-Hamas war as a top issue.
There are more than 3.7 million Arab Americans in the U.S., according to AAI.
Close to 393,000 Arab Americans live in Michigan (which Biden won by just over 154,100 votes in 2020). Another 126,500 live in Pennsylvania (which Biden won by more than 78,500 votes).
AAI estimates two-thirds or more of Arab Americans are Christians, while one-quarter are Muslim.
While Evangelical Christians are among the staunchest supporters of Israel, Orthodox, the Roman Catholic Church and more liberal Protestant denominations — which also have churches in the Holy Land — have pressed for an end to the war and criticized Israel's Gaza bombings and invasion as it seeks to eradicate Hamas.
Another poll released earlier this month by the Arab News and polling firm YouGov gives Trump a 45% to 43% lead over Harris among Arab American voters. Stein gets 4%.
'BITTER PILL'
Late August polls by the Council on American Islamic Relations (CAIR) showed Harris getting 28% of the Muslim vote in six key Electoral College swing states, compared to 30% for Stein and 15% for Trump.
The CAIR poll gave Harris 12% of the Muslim vote in Michigan (a key swing state with a significant Arab-American population) versus 40% for Stein and 18% for Trump.
Robert McCaw, government affairs director for CAIR, said Harris hurt her standing with Muslim voters with recent pronouncements that she wouldn't change anything about the Biden administration policies.
"She stands by the policy of providing Israel with U.S manufactured weapons," McCaw said.
"It's a bitter pill for Muslim voters to swallow," he continued.
McCaw said if margins are tight in the presidential race or key Senate contests, anti-war voters could tip the balance. He also said like any group, Muslim voters can look to other issues, including the economy and social matters. He warns candidates not to take them for granted with Gaza in the backdrop.
"They could be in for a big surprise," he said.
'VITAL VOTES'
One leading anti-war group, Abandon Harris, has endorsed Stein.
Hudhayfah Ahmad, spokesman for the group, said the U.S. administration's "disregard for Palestinian lives has deeply damaged Harris's credibility with a large bloc of voters, including Muslims, progressives and human rights advocates."
"Their votes are vital in this election, and with each bomb dropped in Gaza, Harris's candidacy suffers more," he said.
Harris — who has been heckled by anti-war protesters at some campaign rallies and TV appearances — has tried to walk a political balance beam of supporting Israel's right to defend itself after the Hamas attacks and continued rockets from Hezbollah while calling for a ceasefire. She also snubbed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's speech before Congress in August, and did meet with him at the White House voicing concerns about war deaths.
Harris told CBS News Saturday the U.S. would help defend Israel if Iran strikes back after Israel Defense Forces bombed installations in Iran on Friday.
Ahmad is frustrated with the year-long cycle of top U.S. administration officials, including Harris, calling for and talking up a ceasefire and occasionally criticizing Netanyahu, only to see truce talks falter, coupled with White House and Pentagon pronouncements of "ironclad support for Israel" and continued military support.
"This cycle of empty calls for a ceasefire, followed by a new round of munitions shipments, has become insulting to Muslim voters and others who care about ending the massacres. It's a hollow strategy that tries to pacify the public, while enabling the very acts they claim to denounce. People are tired of the hypocrisy," Ahmad said.
NO FANS OF TRUMPHarris does enjoy backing from Emgage Action, a Muslim group advocacy group that backed Biden in 2020.
Emgage CEO Wa'el Alzayat said "Gaza has been completely destroyed, tens of thousands of civilians have been killed, including many children, and a population of two million has been destitute."
But Alzayat said voting for a third-party candidate will help Trump win the White House.
"Muslims do not need to be reminded of who Donald Trump is," Alzayat said, pointing to the travel bans he proposed from several Muslim countries, moving the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem and backing Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.
Alzayat said Trump also "blessed Netanyahu's expansionism by recognizing Israeli occupation of East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights" and has promised support for Netanyahu on the campaign trail. He sees more hope in Harris, despite her standing by Biden's war stance.
Ahmad is also no fan of Trump.
"Trump's record on Palestine is disastrous — he's championed Israeli expansion and disregarded Palestinian rights altogether. Muslim voters have every reason to distrust him on this issue," he said.
A national poll by The Economist and YouGov shows 36% of Americans sympathize with Israel in the war, 17% back the Palestinians, 25% have equal allegiances and 22% aren't sure. More than two-thirds of conservatives and 45% of wealthy voters back Israel, according to the survey.
The same poll shows 32% of Americans believe Israel is committing genocide in in Gaza, while 35% say they aren't and 32% aren't sure.
'PEACE, NOT WAR'Trump has promised strong support for Israel and is backed by pro-Israeli mega-donor Miriam Adelson and other pro-Israel advocates including billionaire hedge fund manager Bill Ackman. Eighty two percent of white Evangelical Christians — who are among the strongest backers of Israel — support Trump.
But he has also vowed to end the Holy Land war, as well as the war between Russia and Ukraine.
Trump had a group of Muslim leaders and imams — including Dearborn Heights, Michigan Mayor Bill Bazzi — on stage with him during a rally in Michigan on Saturday, welcoming their support.
"We, as Muslims, stand with President Trump because he promises peace, not war," said Imam Belal Alzuhairi. "We are supporting Donald Trump because he promised to end war in the Middle East and Ukraine. The bloodshed has to stop all over the world, and I think this man can make that happen. I personally believe that God saved his life twice for a reason."
Trump has also promised global protections for Christians, promising support for Coptic Christians in the Middle East and pointing to the sectarian dispute between Orthodox Armenians and Muslim Azerbaijanis.
The U.S. provides $3.8 billion in military aid to Israel annually. The Biden-Harris administration backed a $14 billion war aid package and approved a $20 billion long-term weapons sale to Israel earlier this year, and has sent troops, weapons, fighter jets and naval assets during the war with Hamas and Hezbollah and skirmishes with Iran.
Those efforts enjoy bipartisan support. Still, Republicans, including U.S. Sen. Steve Daines of Montana, as well as Trump, argue Biden and Harris have not been supportive enough of Israel.
Trump is also courting Jewish voters, another traditional Democratic voting bloc, and has touted his communications with Netanyahu. Jewish voters backed Biden over Trump by a 68% to 30% margin in 2020, according to the Jewish Virtual Library.
A poll this month by academic research group CHIP50 found some slippage, with Harris holding a 54% to 36% lead over Trump among Jewish voters. A new poll by Channel 12 TV in Israel shows 66% of Israelis back Trump in the U.S. election versus 17% for Harris. More than 90% of Netanyahu backers prefer Trump over Harris, according to the Israeli poll.
This comes as Harris and Democrats press the case that Trump is a fascist who admires Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler.
"I'm not a Nazi. I'm the opposite of a Nazi," Trump told a campaign rally Monday in Atlanta. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the 2024 U.S. presidential election, voter dynamics, and the impact of the Israel-Gaza conflict on political outcomes, fitting under National News as a major current event. Race & Diversity is secondary due to discussions about Arab-American and Muslim voter groups.

title: Election Day looms: How will the counts go and will voters trust the process - and the results?
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
Election Day looms: How will the counts go and will voters trust the process - and the results?

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News | Section: News 
 
 1220
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tuesday's election — which has already seen significant early voting across the country and could see record turnout spurred by the neck-and-neck White House race between former President Donald Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris — will also be a serious test of how much trust the public has in the election system and the government agencies who run it.Right now, those trust levels skew along partisan lines.
A Pew Research Center Poll released Oct. 24 found 42% of Trump voters are not confident the election will run smoothly compared to 90% of Harris voters who trust the system.
According to a Pew survey, 38% of Trump voters have confidence in the counting of mail-in and absentee votes compared to 85% of Harris voters who trust government agencies and poll workers counting the votes.
Close to three-quarters of Harris voters (72%) versus less than one-third of Trump backers (32%) are confident the election system is secure against being hacked.
There is also plenty of curiosity — and some concerns — over how and when ballots will be counted and when winners might be determined not only in the presidential race but also key congressional contests and state ballot measures.
Trump has disputed his 2020 loss to President Joe Biden. Trump led in key battleground states on election night, but Biden overcame those deficits via ensuring counts of mail-in and absentee ballots in the election which occurred in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic.
A number of state and local election agencies have increased security protocols and added more transparency to how ballots are tabulated and secured.
Others are counting absentee, mail-in and other early ballots early this cycle to help get results quicker and avoid delays that could fuel worries about how votes are being counted and results. .
Still, barring some unforeseen turnout trends and definitive exit polls, a winner in the presidential race and other key races are not expected on election night or early Wednesday morning.
In Maryland, polls will be open Tuesday from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Key races include the U.S. Senate race between former Republican governor Larry Hogan and Democratic Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks. GOP U.S. Rep. Andy Harris is being challenged for his Eastern Shore congressional by Democrat Blane Miller.
'COUNTING DOESN'T STOP'In Pitt County, North Carolina near the Atlantic coast, County Elections Director Dave Davis said approved absentee ballot envelopes are fed into voting machines weekly in the run-up to the election.
He said the county has sent out more than 4,100 absentee ballots this year. Close to 87,600 people voted in the 2020 presidential race.
Davis wouldn't talk about election security measures but said "counting doesn't stop" until all ballots are tallied.
North Carolina is one of the key Electoral College battlegrounds between Trump and Harris, and there is some consternation about how long it will take for all votes to be counted in places such as Maricopa County in Arizona. That county, which includes Phoenix and Scottsdale, has a two-page ballot which could add to its already cumbersome counting of early ballots.
The Wisconsin State Board of Elections says all ballots — including in-person and absentee votes — are counted on Election Day and matched to voter registration details in poll books.
"All ballots are counted on Election Day," the state agency says in an explainer on vote counts.
Pennsylvania also does not count absentee ballots until Election Day.
Another key battleground, Michigan, has expanded early voting efforts with early voting centers open and is allowing local clerks to count them ahead of time — though results will not be posted until election night.
STORED IN A VAULTIn Montana (where there is a key U.S. Senate race and ballot measure that would enshrine abortion rights in the state constitution), Gallatin County — which includes Bozeman, Big Sky and Belgrade — will count some absentee votes on Monday as allowed by state law, according to Eric Semerad, who serves as county clerk and elections administrator.
"We will start counting ballots on Monday, Nov. 4. State law allows counties of our size to start counting the day before Election Day, but only until 5 p.m.," Semerad said. "We will then start counting again the morning of Election Day and won't stop until we are finished. Likely this will be sometime late Wednesday."
He said 63,500 absentee ballots have been sent out for this election. Close to 71,000 people voted in Gallatin County in 2020.
Semerad did outline some of the procedures and security measures for counting and securing ballots.
"We will begin opening the secrecy envelopes and removing the ballots on Thursday, October 31st," he said. "All ballots that are opened are kept in large security bags by ballot style which are sealed every night with numbered seals that are logged every time they are sealed or unsealed. Ballots are stored in our office vault that is monitored by a security camera."
State law requires localities to keep counting voting ballots election night.
Semerad said the first set of unofficial results won't be posted online until all voters have finished voting. Voting could continue after polls close if there are long lines.
'CHAIN OF CUSTODY'In Florida, there are ballot measures to legalize marijuana for recreational use and to codify abortion rights into the state constitution superseding state restrictions passed after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022.
Under state law, those measures have to get more than 60% of the vote.
Leah Valenti, supervisor of elections in Charlotte County in southwest Florida, also ran through some of the processes and protocols for counting early mail-in ballots.
Charlotte County — which includes Punta Gorda and Port Charlotte — has sent out more than 45,000 mall-in ballots, Valenti said. More than 116,500 voters cast ballots in the county in 2020.
She said mail-in ballots are date-stamped, voters' identities are confirmed and ballot envelopes are batched and counts are reconciled daily.
They are stored in a secured room.
"Unlike the other office doors which have key card access (RFID), the mail ballots are stored in a dual authenticated secure room, which is under video surveillance. The ballots are stored there until they are opened and counted during a public meeting of the Canvassing Board," Valenti said.
She said voting equipment goes through accuracy testing before ballots are tallied, a new auditing system is being deployed this year and there other "election integrity protocols."
"For instance, any time election materials are transported, two election workers from opposing political parties are required to sign off on chain of custody forms. This ensures transparency and accountability from all sides," Valenti said.
NOT CONNECTEDIn Oregon (where all ballots are submitted by mail), Rochelle Long, Klamath County Clerk in the southern part of the state, said counts are done daily leading up to the election with results posted starting election night.
Klamath County has sent out more than 51,500 ballots for the general election. Just over 36,700 voters cast ballots in the 2020 presidential race in the more rural and conservative county, where Trump carried close to 69% of the vote.
Long said the voting counting process is public and can be seen on livestream in a number of Oregon jurisdictions. There are also safeguards, including multi-party presence during vote counts and transparency for the machine that tallies votes.
"The tally machine is not connected to any outside network," she said. "The vote tally machine is in a locked room on camera and can be viewed publicly via live stream." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the upcoming national election, voter trust in the electoral process, and procedural details across multiple states, aligning most closely with 'National News' as a major current event. Local government aspects are mentioned but secondary to the national scope.

title: AP call: Democrat Angela Alsobrooks wins election to Senate
author: Tom McCall
content:
AP call: Democrat Angela Alsobrooks wins election to Senate

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: State News 
 
 100
 Words

 Democrat Angela Alsobrooks won the U.S. Senate seat in Maryland on Tuesday. Alsobrooks defeated Republican former Gov. Larry Hogan in a closely watched race with control of the Senate potentially at stake.Alsobrooks prevailed in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans 2-1, but Hogan's popularity as a two-term governor made him one of the strongest competitors for a Senate seat in Maryland in decades.
Alsobrooks, who will be the state's first Black senator, is the chief executive of Prince George's County, Maryland's second most populous jurisdiction next to the nation's capital. The Associated Press declared Alsobrooks the winner at 9:32 p.m.
