title: Dorchester Republicans, eager for change, rally behind Trump as results come in
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester Republicans, eager for change, rally behind Trump as results come in

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — As Sen. Johnny Mautz said his goodbyes just before 9 p.m. at a Tuesday night Dorchester Republican Central Committee watch party, he left saying the three words that became a rallying cry this election cycle for Donald Trump's presidential campaign — "fight, fight, fight."Attendees cheered and carried on that optimism before calling it a night, just hours before the former president claimed victory over Democratic opponent Kamala Harris. While some sighed in disappointment when Democrat Angela Alsobrooks clinched the U.S. Senate seat over Republican former Gov. Larry Hogan, the hopes for a Donald Trump victory remained high.
Earlier Tuesday evening, Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) implored around 30 Republicans gathered for the watch party in a Bay Country Security garage to carry on the values and messages of the Republican Party — no matter the eventual results.
"That message has got to carry on, whether it's one house, two houses, all three, or God forbid, none," Mautz said. "We've got to be prepared for whatever is coming to us, because there is no walking away. There's no ignoring the reality of the division that's in our country right now."
"Make sure we just keep pounding home the priorities and the principles of what our country is founded on, and we're going to succeed," he continued. "And we'll do it because of you guys."
Bill Travers, from East New Market, voted for Trump and felt optimistic while watching the race. He paid close attention to the swing states as numbers came in, standing up to celebrate when he saw Trump hold leads in Georgia, North Carolina and Pennsylvania, three states the Republican candidate later won.
Travers said his support for the former president was never in doubt. He wants to see change in office, disappointed with the country's trajectory under President Joe Biden.
"It's a no-brainer," Travers said. "We need new leadership."
While Travers thinks Trump "needs to be a little more humble," he said the president-elect aligns with his stance against abortion as well as alleviating his concerns regarding gas prices and interest rates.
Tyler Sears, a 17-year-old from Dorchester County, watched closely, with future college endeavors and worries about paying bills among the practical issues on his mind. When asked if he felt the national election would impact his immediate future, Sears said "without a doubt."
The high school senior saw Trump as the candidate who would most benefit him moving forward, saying he likely would've voted Trump if he was 18.
"I'm praying it's Trump," Sears said.
Many hoped Tuesday's election would bring not just a second Trump presidency, but a calming in political division.
Cambridge resident Sandra Potter, 79, was rooting for Trump. She said she's "never seen an election like this," noting the divisiveness it's created and the relationships with friends and family it's splintered.
Two of her children, one a Democrat and one a Republican, disagreed with one another this cycle but still remained on friendly terms. That's something Potter wants to see on a larger scale.
"It's time we pick ourselves up by the bootstraps and move forward," Potter said. " … I hope we never see this discord again. I hope we learn from this election."
Though the watch party's focus was largely directed at the presidential battle, Mautz said in an interview that he noticed a "super high level of attention" on local and national races on Election Day.
"I think the intensity of the national election has intensified all of the candidacies," Mautz said.
As the night grew older, members of the Dorchester County Republican Central Committee and local Republicans celebrated Trump's win in Texas, with one attendee shouting, "God bless Texas." It gave Trump a 178-113 lead in the electoral college, an advantage he never relinquished.
Adorned in a camo 'Ultra MAGA' cap, Potter vowed that despite what she views as tiring political rhetoric from both sides of the aisle, Trump was her preferred choice to assume the role as the country's next commander-in-chief.
"I think he does absolutely take care of our country," Potter said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the 2024 U.S. presidential election, specifically the reactions of Dorchester Republicans to Trump's victory. While it includes local community activities, the core subject is a national political event, making 'National News' the primary classification. 'Local Life' is a secondary consideration due to the local Republican gathering, but the election's national scope dominates.

title: Many election results known by Wednesday, some races still awaiting final counts
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Many election results known by Wednesday, some races still awaiting final counts

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 652
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Election night produced some decisive victories on the Mid-Shore, in Maryland and throughout the nation. Despite predictions that it may take several days before results were known, by Wednesday morning, many races had been called, though some ballots remained to be counted.Donald Trump secured his presidential victory when Wisconsin was called in the early hours of Wednesday, culminating the former president's comeback campaign that outperformed expectations.
Going into election night, many predicted it might take days for the results of the presidential election to be tallied. Trump performed better than he did during the 2020 election against President Joe Biden. His Democratic opponent for the seat, Kamala Harris, was unable to carry the necessary votes in swing states to secure her victory.
"I want to thank the American people for the extraordinary honor of being elected your 47th president and your 45th president," Trump told cheering supporters in Mar a Lago, Florida, Tuesday night before his victory was confirmed.
In the closely watched race to replace outgoing U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.), Democrat Angela Alsobrooks faced Republican Larry Hogan, a former Maryland governor. The race was expected to be close going into election night, but the Associated Press called the race for Alsobrooks just hours after polls closed in the state.
Alsobrooks, the current Prince George's County executive, took the lead as precincts began reporting results Tuesday night. With nearly all precincts reporting, as of Wednesday she had collected about 52% of votes to Hogan's 45%, a wide enough margin that the remaining mail-in and provisional ballots to be tallied will not change the outcome.
Alsobrooks' victory marked a historic moment for the state — the election of its first Black female senator. She, along with Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester of Delaware, will join only a handful of Black women who have served in the office when she takes her oath of office in January.
"Now, it's remarkable to think that in two years, America will celebrate its 250th birthday, and in all those years, there have been more than 2,000 people who have served in the United States Senate, and only three have looked like me," Alsobrooks said on stage at her watch party in College Park Tuesday night.
U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) secured his reelection to Maryland's 1st District Congressional seat, a position he has held since 2010.
Harris, who represents the Eastern Shore, had secured 62.8% of the vote in his race as of Wednesday morning, defeating Democratic challenger Blane Miller. About 82% of ballots in the district had been counted at that time.
But while some victories were able to be called, others need to wait until more ballots have been canvassed. In Maryland, election judges will tally remaining mail-in and provisional ballots over the next few weeks.
Among the races still too close to definitively call are all three Talbot County Board of Education races. Cynthia Marrah Jurrius led the District 6 race by just 46 votes as of Wednesday morning. The county's other Board of Education races had only a few hundred votes separating the candidates.
After polls closed at 8 p.m. Tuesday, unofficial votes from the day were made available on the state board of elections website. Those results included early voting totals, mail-in ballots canvassed prior to Election Day and vote tallies from Tuesday.
Provisional ballots will be canvassed on Wednesday, Nov. 13. Counting of mail-in ballots ends on Friday, Nov. 15.
There were more than 6,000 mail-in ballots requested in Talbot County, of which 3,273 had been accepted as of Tuesday. In Caroline County, more than 2,400 mail-in ballots were requested and 880 had been accepted. More than 3,300 mail-in ballots were sent to Dorchester County voters. Dorchester County will not begin canvassing mail-in votes until Thursday.
Official verification of the vote count and certification of Maryland's election is scheduled for Nov. 15. Statewide certification is expected by Dec. 5, within 30 days of the election, as required by law.
Jesse Yeatman contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on national election results, including the presidential race and Senate contests, which are core components of national news. While local races (e.g., Talbot County Board of Education) are mentioned, the primary coverage centers on nationwide electoral outcomes and significant political figures like Trump and Harris.

title: 'I learned to not judge': Veterans Day's origins and contemporary commemorations across the country
author: Staff reports
content:
'I learned to not judge': Veterans Day's origins and contemporary commemorations across the country

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff reports | Section: National 
 
 1571
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The origins of Veterans Day in the U.S. date back to 1921 with the burial of an unknown World War I American soldier on a hillside overlooking the Potomac River in Arlington National Cemetery.Britain and France had already memorialized the end of WWI with burials of unknown soldiers and ceremonies on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month in 1918, the day the war came to an official close.
World War I — or the Great War — saw more 17 million people killed across Europe.
It was violent sea change for Europe and the world.
It sparked the Russian Revolution, the end of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, Ottoman Empire and the downfall of monarchies across Europe including those countries and Germany. The age of kings, queens and emperors ruling Europe had come to an end.
The U.S. entered the war in 1917.
The Spanish Flu pandemic, which killed as many as 50 million people.
The war was the development of new and deadlier warfare and its aftermath set the stage for the rise of Adolf Hitler and Nazis in Germany and horrors of World War II.
The war saw the development of tanks, military aircraft, chemical weapons and flamethrowers and the advent of zippers, sanitary pads and napkins, blood banks and trench coats.
An annual commemoration of the formal cease fire was first known as Armistice Day.
A Congressional resolution in 1926 officially named Armistice Day, and it became a national holiday 12 years later.
But according to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, in 1947 in Birmingham, Alabama, the first celebration under the name Veterans Day was held with parades and other festivities to honor all veterans.
Communities throughout the nation, continue the tradition of holding Veterans Day ceremonies.
That includes some events at schools and colleges.
In Washington state, Big Lake Elementary School's Veterans Day celebration Thursday included a flag retirement ceremony by members of the Naval Air Station Whidbey Island Search and Rescue unit.
SHARING EXPERIENCESVeterans enrolled in colleges in Elizabeth City, North Carolina, shared their experiences Thursday at a Veterans Day observance event.
During the event, veterans attending the College of The Albrmarle, Mid-Atlantic Christian University, and Elizabeth City State University talked about their military experiences and how their decision to serve their country had affected their lives and career choices.
Bobby Martin, a student at MACU, joined the U.S. Navy after high school in 1977. His dad, a Vietnam era veteran and minister, was his role model, he said. When his dad's colleagues visited their home to enjoy meals and football games, Martin said he heard first-hand accounts about what it meant to serve in the military.
"These men were inspirations to me," Martin said. "I have been to the North Pole, Europe, Middle East and East Africa while in the Navy. I'm 66 years old, put my wife and child through school, and now I'm working on my ministry degree at Mid-Atlantic Christian University. "
Wendra Costly, a U.S. Army veteran now enrolled at COA, recalled how she left the U.S. Army in 2018 wondering what she would do. While her job in the military was in information technology, and there are promising job opportunities in that field, Costly wasn't persuaded IT would provide her with the long-term career she was seeking.
And as a wife and mother of four, Costly said she knew it was important to have a rewarding career with good pay.
"I called the aviation department (at COA) and got some information about their program. I finally decided that aviation was the way to go for (me in) our area," she said.
Costly also talked about some of the challenges veterans face when they go back to school.
"We are older, and we have had some experiences that a good amount of college adults will not be able to relate to," she said.
But overcoming challenges is something you learn to do in the military, Costly said.
"Just like all the hard things you accomplished in the military like training, running in the rain, heat and cold — we can do them," she said.
Michelle Barnes, who is enrolled at ECSU, spent eight years working as an aviation electronics technician in the U.S. Navy. Barnes said the fear of traveling to unfamiliar places and the potential of having to face danger nearly delayed her decision to enlist.
But she's glad she did enlist. Barnes said her job in the Navy was challenging and provided steady pay.
Today, she's glad she accepted the challenges the military offered. She met her husband, who is currently enlisted, while she was in service. Serving in the military also has helped her pay for her college expenses.
"Joining the military was the best decision that I could have ever made at the age of 25," Barnes said. "I decided to embrace all that the Navy had to offer me in honor of those who fought and died for this country's freedom. "
Barnes said she will graduate in 2026 with a bachelor of science degree in aviation science with a concentration in professional aeronautics and a minor in unmanned aerial systems.
Catherine Edmonds, ECSU's interim chancellor, applauded her colleagues at MACU and COA for helping area veterans return to school to learn new skills. She also thanked the veterans who attended the event.
"Although we work every day to assist and honor our veterans, today is set aside specifically to recognize all of our veterans for their service and sacrifices," she said. "We are a military-friendly university, proud to continue a tradition of excellence serving military members, veterans, and their families."
Bane Angles, vice president of student services at MACU and also a veteran, said he was impressed by the student veterans' stories. He also was glad, he said, that the city's three institutions of higher education could come together and offer an event like Thursday's.
"There are many important lessons I learned from serving in the military," Angles said. "Not least of these is the importance of unity. No matter where a person is from, what accent they have, what race they are, or creed they follow, all are part of something bigger.
"In a society that is too divided for many reasons, we can learn from our armed forces that a higher purpose brings us together in unity. I pray for the day when our country is not divided but is united," Angles said.
COA President Jack Bagwell said the community college was proud to host Thursday's event. He also applauded the veterans in the audience for their service and urged them to help the college serve them better.
"We believe we can get better everyday," he said. "With you helping us there are things we have not thought of yet that will serve you better. Please share those. We are always open to your feedback. We're certainly open to how we can be more military friendly."
BAND OF BROTHERSIn Ohio, Athens High School held a special assembly for its students to talk and hear from local veterans.
Melissa Myers, student council advisor and a French teacher at Athens High, said the event is important.
Myers recounted when she volunteered at an assisted living home while in high school and formed a bond with a Belgian woman who'd lived through the World Wars and how it changed her perspective.
"You can study history and read books and watch movies, but you never truly get an understanding of what people have gone through," Myers said. "It's (about) making those stories come to life and having a better appreciation."
Myers' perspective is also shaped by her father, who served in the Army National Guard.
"Hopefully for our high school students it helps our young people understand, no matter what your positions are on various things, everyone who serves, they're serving their country. It's one single vision," she said.
The main event at the Veterans Day assembly was a speech from Chad Springer, associate superintendent at the local school district and a former U.S. Army sergeant.
Springer felt it was important to share his experience with the students, even if he personally prefers to celebrate Veterans Day quietly.
"Some veterans like to go to the public events and things like that," Springer said. "Generally, I don't, because service is very personal to me, because all of us had our own reasons for serving."
Springer told the story of his uncles, Bob and Howard. Howard was a United States Army Ranger during the Second World War, while Bob served in the Army during the Korean War. Bob was able to rise to the rank of sergeant first class in three years, an impressive feat that would've taken years to achieve during peacetime, but he carried the scars of Korea with him for the rest of his life.
"Most of the family saw him as a larger than life man with a short fuse, a quick temper and a love of the drink," Springer explained.
Springer said that serving in the military and experiencing the challenges of military service gave him a different perspective on his Uncle Bob than the rest of his family had and that had he not served, he would've remembered his uncles very differently.
"I learned to not judge lest ye be judged, because when it came down to it, we were all needed by each other. I became a brother to those around me," Springer said, recounting his time in the Army. "When someone needed me, their needs were met. When I needed something, others were always there for me. It instilled in myself a sense of community and belonging that I have never felt before nor since." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the historical origins of Veterans Day in the U.S. and its contemporary national commemorations, including events across multiple states. While it touches on educational institutions hosting veteran-related activities, the primary subject is the national observance and historical significance of Veterans Day, aligning most closely with 'National News.'

title: Did all of Kamala Harris' celebrity endorsements actually hurt her campaign against Donald Trump?
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Did all of Kamala Harris' celebrity endorsements actually hurt her campaign against Donald Trump?

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 331
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Vice President Kamala Harris picked up a parade of celebrity endorsements in the 2024 White House race against former President Donald Trump.In the end, they didn't work out for her with Trump winning the Electoral College and the popular vote.
Voters anxious over the economy and inflation favored Trump.
Harris's campaign focused on Trump's "threats to democracy" and abortion rights. There were even some abortion rights ballot measures that passed in states carried by Trump.
Harris' celebrity backers included Taylor Swift, LeBron James, Beyonce, Ricky Martin, Jennifer Lopez, Robert De Niro, Jon Bon Jovi, Lady Gaga, James Taylor, Tyler Perry, Oprah Winfrey, Jimmy Kimmel and Bruce Springsteen.
The list of celebrities opposing Trump and backing Harris — who was installed at the top of ticket after President Joe Biden was pressured to quit by Democratic donors and power brokers — was lengthy.
Some Hispanic musicians, rappers and actors were upset with comedian Tony Hinchcliffe calling Puerto Rico "a floating island of garbage."
Meanwhile, Trump's campaign kept focusing on voters' concerns about inflation — with prices up more than 20% since Harris and Biden took office in 2021.
For many voters, Harris and Democrats are viewed as the party of elites. The celebrity endorsements might have fed into that narrative.
Trump carried majorities of Hispanic men and white women and made gains with first-time voters and Hispanic women.
Trump ended up carrying Electoral College battlegrounds and won the popular votes. Harris' also lost some voters on either side of the war in the Middle East between Israel and Iranian proxies Hamas and Hezbollah.
Supporters of Israel don't trust Harris after she snubbed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's speech before Congress in August.
Arab American, Muslim and antiwar voters are upset with Harris and Biden over U.S. military support for Israel and the number of deaths in Gaza in the war that sparked after Hamas' Oct. 7, 2023 attacks.
Trump did enjoy some celebrity backers including Danica Patrick, Brett Favre, Hulk Hogan, Kid Rock, James Woods, Joe Rogan, Dana White and 'Dr. Phil' McGraw. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the 2024 U.S. presidential election, Kamala Harris's campaign strategies, and political outcomes, which aligns with 'National News.' While celebrity endorsements are mentioned, the core content revolves around political events rather than entertainment. 'Business/Economy' is a secondary factor due to inflation discussions but is not the primary focus.

title: Voter turnout: 13M more nonvoters than Trump backers; Harris got 10% fewer votes than Biden
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Voter turnout: 13M more nonvoters than Trump backers; Harris got 10% fewer votes than Biden

 November 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: News 
 
 1205
 Words 

 Read News Document

 More than 89 million voting eligible Americans didn't vote in the 2024 elections, according to the latest tallies collected by the University of Florida's Election Lab.That accounts for more than 36.4% of the U.S. total electorate of 244.7 million people (voters and nonvoters).
There are still some votes being counted in California and Arizona.
But as it stands as of Thursday, Nov. 14, there were 13.2 million more nonvoters than supporters of now President-elect Donald Trump in the 2024 White House race.
Trump — who defeated Vice President Kamala Harris — has received close to 75.9 million votes, according to tallies Thursday from The Associated Press.
That accounts for just over 50% of the popular vote. But if nonvoters are included Trump got 31% of the electorate (voting and nonvoting).
Harris, the sitting U.S. vice president, has received close to 72.9 million votes, as of Thursday's counts.
That is more than 16.2 million fewer votes than the number of non-voters. As it stands, Harris got 29.7% of the total U.S. electorate.
Harris was installed at the top of the ticket after President Joe Biden was pressured by Democratic Party leaders and donors to quit the race in late July over concerns about his advanced age. There were some polls showing U.S. voters viewing that installation as 'undemocratic.'
Biden got close to 81.3 million in 2020 when he defeated Trump. That is more than 8.3 million more votes than Harris got in 2024. There were also more than 4.1 million fewer voters overall in 2024 compared to 2020.
Ani Ruhil, associate dean for research and planning and professor at Ohio University's Voinovich School of Leadership and Public Service, said ongoing vote counts could impact final turnout figures.
But Ruhil sees lower turnout as a key trend line in the 2024 race that saw Trump return to the White House.
"Only seven states exceeded their 2020 turnout rate — Georgia, Michigan, North Dakota, Vermont and Wisconsin," Ruhil said. "Washington, D.C., had an especially poor showing compared to 2020. So did Oregon, New Jersey, Maryland, Alaska, Illinois, and Utah."
The number of voters casting ballots in 2024 was down 11.6% in New Jersey, 11.2% in Illinois, 8.9% in Oregon and 4.6% in Washington state compared to 2020.
Nationally, turnout stands at 63.6%, according to the University of Florida. Ruhil said turnout in 2020 — which totaled 66.6% nationally — was a political aberration.
The Biden-Trump 2020 race occurred in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, which saw more than 1.1 million deaths in the U.S., millions of workers facing job cuts and reduced hours, mask mandates and closures of schools, business and social events.
"Turnout was fanned by fear and anger," he said.
"In comes President Biden, with the singular charge of steering the country through the pandemic, and of making sure the economy did not fall to pieces. But by 2023, as we came out of the pandemic, inflation had taken its toll. Now was not the fear of a virus, but rather of gaping holes in the pocketbook. But there was no comforting plan being put forth by the White House," Ruhil continued.
He sees some voter fatigue with continued efforts by federal and state prosecutors to go after Trump.
Seventy percent of voters said the U.S. is headed in the wrong direction, with two-thirds stressed about inflation and the economy. Prices are up more than 20% since the pandemic and from when Biden and Harris took office in 2021, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Voters worried about the economy and high prices favored Trump in the 2024 race, according to exit polls.
The war in Gaza between Israel and Hamas after the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks also challenged Harris.
Anti-war voters (including Muslims and Arab Americans) are upset with U.S. military support for Israel. In the other corner, supporters of Israel (including more conservative Jewish voters) didn't trust Harris to continue U.S. support for Israel . The U.S. has allocated $17.9 billion war aid to Israel since Hamas's 2023 attacks, according to Brown University.
Harris got just over 80,000 fewer votes in Michigan, where the Israel-Hamas war is an issue for Arab-American and Muslim voters, than Biden 2020.
She lost to Trump by just over 80,600 votes in Michigan.
Ruhil said the enthusiasm was let out of the turnout balloon for many Democratic voters.
"The late switch, fevered fundraising, and a hastily assembled campaign did nothing to instill confidence," he said, stressing the lack of a convincing economic message from Harris.
Harris' campaign raised more than $1 billion and had another $649 million in backing from outside groups, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. Trump raised $381.5 million and was aided by $711 million in outside spending, according to CRP.
Harris' campaign focused heavily on support for abortion rights, casting Trump as a fascist threat to democracy and procuring celebrity endorsements including Oprah Winfrey, Jennifer Lopez, Beyonce, Willie Nelson and Bruce Springsteen.
The effort fell short with Harris underperforming Biden by 8.4 million votes (or 10.3%) nationally. She saw lower turnout or flat support levels in key Electoral College battlegrounds that Trump won.
Harris got 6.6% fewer votes than Biden in Arizona.
There was also the dynamic of Trump carrying states such as Montana, Missouri, Arizona and Florida, where there were abortion rights measures also on the ballot.
Those measures all passed and in Florida an abortion rights measure got 57% of the vote (failing to meet the state's 60% threshold). Trump got 56% of the vote.
In Montana, Trump carried the state with 58%. An abortion rights measure got the same percentage.
Trump favors allowing states to decide the abortion issue versus Harris, who backs nationally enshrining abortion rights.
Abortion rights groups were among the top backers of Harris.
"This result is devastating. There has been no greater champion for reproductive freedom than Vice President Kamala Harris," said Mini Timmaraju, president and CEO of Reproductive Freedom for All, a leading abortion rights advocacy group.
"We know the American people are with us, and they showed us that when they passed ballot measures and elected candidates in key states to protect their rights, said Timmaraju, who worries about Trump and the GOP in charge of the White House and Congress.
Harris and Democrats had hoped for a wave of women voters supporting abortion rights in the race against Trump.
But exit polls showed Trump carrying a majority of white women who voted, and voters were more evenly split on which presidential candidate they trusted on the abortion issue than in pre-election polls.
Abortion rights opponents argue Harris' focus on expansive abortion rights turned off some voters.
"Kamala Harris and Tim Walz support abortion anytime, anywhere, and under any circumstances. Supported by the abortion industry and its allies, Harris and Walz campaigned with fanatical fervor on abortion — and the voters rejected them," said Carol Tobias, president of National Right to Life.
Trump carried 58% of the Catholic vote versus 40% for Harris, according to NBC News exit polls. In 2020, Biden and Trump were evenly split with Catholics (49% to 50%), according to the Associated Press.
Trump won 63% of the votes from white working class women, made inroads with Hispanics (especially Hispanic men) and edged Harris with working class households, according to NBC News exit polls.
According to the University of Florida, there were 15.5 million fewer early votes in 2024 compared to 2020 (85.9 million versus 101.45 million).
That's a 15% drop.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on national election results, voter turnout statistics, and political dynamics at the national level, including comparisons between candidates and nationwide trends. While economic factors and specific state-level data are mentioned, the core subject is the 2024 U.S. presidential election as a national news event.

title: Lessons learned in the presidential election
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Lessons learned in the presidential election

 November 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 775
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Even before he is sworn into office in January, Donald Trump has firmly secured a prominent place in American history books.He is only the second president in U.S. history elected to two nonconsecutive terms.
The road to that Outcome was a long and winding one.
It was a road where Trump repeatedly challenged conventional wisdom and proved it to be wrong at every step of the way.
Below is a recap of conventional wisdom from the 2024 presidential election with conventional wisdom being defined as a widely accepted assumption and prediction.
Below each conventional wisdom is a recap of actual Outcomes relative to conventional wisdom.
Convential Wisdom: Donald Trump was finished in politics due to being impeached twice in the U.S. House of Representatives during his first presidential term, federal criminal indictments (still pending), and state felony convictions (still being appealed).
Outcome: With a combination of resilience, determination and perseverance, Trump triumphed over 15 Republicans for the Republican Party's 2024 presidential nomination.
Convential Wisdom: In a June debate between Biden and Trump, both would deliver solid performances.
Outcome: Biden's debate performance was arguably the worst in history.
Convential Wisdom: Despite his debate performance, Biden would stay in a reelection grudge match with Trump.
Outcome: In July, Biden abruptly withdrew his bid for reelection and immediately endorsed Kamala Harris, a move that led to her being the Democratic Party's standard bearer.
Convential Wisdom: Harris would not do well in her only debate with Trump.
Outcome: Harris exceeded expectations which gave her campaign a much-needed boost.
Convential Wisdom: There would be at least one "October surprise" from the Biden administration.
Outcome: An "October surprise" came early but not from the Biden administration. It came in July when Trump narrowly escaped death from an assassination attempt.
Convential Wisdom: Harris could mobilize support from women voters with two campaign messages. One was a message used very effectively by Democratic candidates in the 2022 midterm elections — vote against Republicans as they are not pro-choice on abortion. The second message was now women voters had another opportunity to elect a woman as president of the United States.
Outcome: More women than the Harris campaign expected concluded that the state of the economy and high levels of inflation were their top concerns. Concurrently, they also concluded that despite electing a woman for president of the United States was a long-awaited opportunity, Kamala Harris was not that woman.
Convential Wisdom: Trump would experience the same lack of support from working class voters, urban voters, Black voters, young voters, Asian voters and Jewish voters that Republican presidential candidates have historically experienced.
Outcome: Trump's support from all these groups exceeded all expectations. He won the "blue wall" states of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin as well as four other "swing states."
Convential Wisdom: Despite being fiercely loyal to President Biden and all of his progressive policies for almost four years, Kamala Harris could tell voters she would be a very different president than Biden.
Outcome: Voters rejected that messaging after Harris answered a question on what she would do differently from President Biden with: "Nothing that I can think of." U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders also cast aspersions on her integrity when he said publicly Harris was a progressive who would say whatever she needed to say to get elected.
Convential Wisdom: Kamala Harris' running mate, Tim Walz, could help offset Trump campaign messages that Harris has been and is a radical San Francisco California progressive. Walz could be branded as a quintessential American "everyman" — a former high school teacher, former high school football coach, military veteran, former member of Congress and now governor of Minnesota.
Outcome: Walz was quickly and negatively viewed by voters as not ready for prime time due to frequent verbal gaffes and his answers (misleading at best) to questions about his background, especially his military service record.
Convential Wisdom: The November election popular vote outcome was expected to be a tossup that could result in a narrow popular vote win for either candidate.
Outcome: Trump won with 50.38% of the popular vote compared to 47.96% of the popular vote for Harris.
Convential Wisdom: The November election Electoral College vote outcome was expected to be a tossup that could result in a narrow Electoral College win for either candidate.
Outcome: With 270 Electoral College votes needed to win, Trump received 312 Electoral College votes compared to Harris' 226 Electoral College votes. Trump was the first Republican president elected since 2004 to win both the popular vote and the Electoral College vote.
Going forward, the 2024 presidential election confirmed two absolute truths about conventional wisdom for political candidates, campaigns, pundits, voters and others.
Never assume anything will happen at any until the polls close on Election Day.
Anything may happen at any time until the polls close on Election Day. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes the 2024 U.S. presidential election, focusing on national political outcomes, candidate strategies, and historical significance. While it touches on local aspects of the election process, the primary focus is on national-level events, making 'National News' the most appropriate category.

title: What lessons did we learn from the election?
author: Staff Writer
content:
What lessons did we learn from the election?

 November 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 669
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What did we learn from the majority of America's voters on Nov. 5?We learned that the majority of America's voters want border security. Americans are tired of millions of undocumented people from any place in the world flooding into America. We want them to come legally. The reports of gangs growing in our cities, apartment buildings taken over, murders and rampant stabbings have been an emotional weight from which Americans want relief.
Americans are tired of spending more money at the grocery store and coming home with fewer products. Every week brings price increases, and Americans pay checks are not keeping up. Employers have been suffering to keep employees who are desperate for higher wages.
Employers can no longer get by with $10 or $12 an hour as the new expected minimum wage has become at least $15. To keep a good employee though will take $20 an hour if you want them to stay. This has put a strain on small businesses in America who are struggling to produce enough income to pay workers and keep the lights on. The cost of goods must decrease and wages have to stabilize.
Americans want lower interest rates. A 6% house loan is still making in tough on America's homebuyers. A 30-year mortgage on a $450,000 house is $2,158.38 if you have $90,000 to put down. A six-year car payment on a $45,000 car is $596.62 if you put $9,000 down. Most Americans need a house and car. So you see the reason why people are desperate to make more money. Add on to this a $1,200 a month grocery bill for a family of four.
Americans have grown weary hearing about male athletes in women's sports. We are also tired of hearing about men in women's bathrooms.
Americans also displayed their disdain for legacy media. I personally thought it would be tough for Trump to overcome all the major networks. I didn't see how anyone could beat NBC, ABC, CBS, CNN and MSNBC, the New York Times, The Washington Post and almost every other major media entity in the nation, but he did. He beat them good.
One network supported Trump throughout the entire election, and it was Fox News. On election night they had the highest ratings of all the networks. The majority of America's voters no longer believe much of what they hear on America's major media networks, which is sad since we all pay so much in subscriptions to access these stations.
Trump spent three hours with Joe Rogan on a podcast that reached millions of Rogan's viewers. Harris didn't have time for Rogan. Look for many more podcasters to grow in influence in the days ahead.
We learned that women did go to polls to vote, and many of them voted for Trump.
Kamala Harris had over $1 billion to spend on her election The networks were flooded with political ads, and it still wasn't enough. Sadly, it's reported that her campaign is $20 million in debt with no way in sight to cover outstanding costs. The big parties and celebrity gatherings were massively expensive. No cost was curbed. A billion dollars was spent without concern or limitation. Can you imagine how she would have handled the nation's finances and run our country?
We also learned that national celebrities don't impress America's voters all that much. They will pay thousands to hear Taylor Swift sing, but her support of Kamala Harris was overall ignored. Many of Swift's followers aren't old enough to vote. Oprah Winfrey, Beyonce, George Clooney, Bruce Springsteen, Lady Gaga, Katy Perry, Julia Roberts, etc., etc. are all-star entertainers, but the average person in America just wasn't swayed by them when it came time to vote.
The election is over. Let's pray that Congress will work together to end the wars in the world, lower inflation, make medical care available for all people on all levels of their need. Let's pray for a safe and peaceful America where people are entering our country legally and safely and for four years of prosperity and peace. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes post-election insights, focusing on national political trends, voter priorities, media influence, and economic concerns. While it touches on business/economy and public safety topics, the central theme revolves around national political events and media coverage, making 'National News' the most accurate classification.
