While it references a local community's perspective, the core content relates to national constitutional debates and federal leadership, aligning most closely with 'National News.'

title: Anti-abortion groups want Musk, Trump to ‘defund’ Planned Parenthood
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Anti-abortion groups want Musk, Trump to ‘defund’ Planned Parenthood

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1123
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Anti-abortion activists want Elon Musk to look at eliminating federal funding for Planned Parenthood as part of his austerity measures for President Donald Trump.Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) efforts have resulted in staffing and operational cuts across multiple U.S. agencies and turned off funding to various contractors and other groups who receive federal money.
Anti-abortion groups want Musk and President Donald Trump, who believes abortion rights should be left up to individual U.S. states, to look into an turn off funding for Planned Parenthood, the nation's largest abortion provider which also offers other health services.
Federal funding cannot be used for abortion services. Planned Parenthood receives federal money for Medicaid reimbursements for other health services as well federal grants for health centers and non-abortion programs.
'ELIMINATE'Public money for Planned Parenthood has long been targeted by conservative groups opposed to abortion rights. Such an effort with Musk would draw his DOGE efforts into the long divisive abortion rights debate.
"Planned Parenthood's total revenue for 2023 (the latest year numbers are available) was over $2 billion. Yet, Planned Parenthood received over $699.3 million in taxpayer funds from various government 'reimbursements and grants.' Taxpayers should not be supplementing an industry that takes the lives of pre-born children and brings in over $2 billion in revenue. We are hopeful that the Trump administration will look into the taxpayer money used to supplement the nation's largest abortion provider and eliminate the funding scheme," said Laura Echevarria, National Right to Life's director of communications and press secretary.
A contingent of anti-abortion and socially conservative advocates have written to Musk as well as the Office of Management and Budget asking them to examine Planned Parenthood's federal funding.
"According to the Government Accountability Office (GAO), Planned Parenthood Health Centers received about $22 billion in Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) grants and $53 billion in payments from public health coverage programs from 2019 to 2021. Planned Parenthood Federation of America affiliates received $148 million in HHS grants and $1.5 billion in Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP payments, with an additional $108 million or so for Planned Parenthood's regional organizations," reads the Feb. 13 letter.
It was spearheaded by former U.S. Vice President Mike Pence's Advancing American Freedom group. Signators include AAF President Tim Chapman, Faith & Freedom Coalition Chairman Ralph Reed and Jennie Bradley Lichter, president of March for Life Action.
The Southern Baptist Convention, CatholicVote, Oregon Right to Life and other groups are also asking abortion rights opponents to contact Trump and Congress asking them to restrict Planned Parenthood funding.
ORTL Executive Director Lois Anderson said in an email to supporters that Planned Parenthood provides 40% of the abortions in the U.S.
A NEW 'DEFUND FIGHT'In a Feb. 3 memo, the Planned Parenthood Federation of America outlined the impact yanked government funding could have on its operations and patients.
"If patients are prevented from getting quality, affordable Planned Parenthood health services like birth control, cancer screenings, and STI (sexually transmitted infections) testing and treatment, and more, the grave consequences would bring lasting harm to communities nationwide. Many patients who come to Planned Parenthood health centers get their insurance through Medicaid, and have few care options — as many Planned Parenthood health centers are located in health provider deserts, making it hard to access any health care," PPFA said in the memo.
Planned Parenthood said it had more than 2 million patients nationwide in 2022, conducted close to 213,000 breast exams, approximately 198,000 pap tests and 2.3 million birth control services.
More than half of Planned Parenthood 's patients are lower income and on Medicaid. Close to half of Planned Parenthood's patients are people of color, according to the group.
Musk and Trump ally Vivek Ramaswamy brought up potential Planned Parenthood defunding after Trump's election win. Musk has since taken control of DOGE efforts with job cuts across the U.S. government. Musk said last year he does not support abortion rights after viability.
Alexis McGill Johnson, president and CEO of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said after that pronouncement such an action would deny people health care and wreak "havoc on our public health system."
"We've been here before — we are not new to shutdown and 'defund' fights. We fended off a number of these attacks during Trump's first term — and Planned Parenthood health centers are still there serving millions of patients across the nation." McGill Johnson said.
After the 2022 Dobbs' decision overturning Roe v. Wade, abortion rights were sent back to the states.
Some conservative states, such as Utah, Alabama and Florida, have sought to restrict abortion rights post-Roe.
Voters in other states, such as Montana, Missouri, Maryland, New York, Nevada and Arizona — approved ballot measures in November enshrining abortion rights into their state constitutions.
All of those states, except New York, went for Trump in the November presidential race over Vice President Kamala Harris, who made expansive abortion rights a centerpiece of her White House bid.
Trump favors a state-by-state approach to abortion and does not appear interested in a federal abortion ban or restriction on abortion-inducing medications.
Medication abortions make up 63% of all pregnancy terminations in the U.S., according to the Guttmacher Institute.
Trump has restricted U.S. funding internationally for groups providing abortions.
There are also GOP bills in Congress to defund Planned Parenthood.
PROTESTS OR DIVIDENDSProgressives and other left-wing activists held protests on President's Day, Feb. 17. to rally against Trump's early days in office, his ties to wealthy interests including billionaires and oil and gas companies as well as Musk's DOGE austerity efforts.
"While Trump appoints 13 billionaires to his cabinet and Musk, Bezos and Zuckerberg see their wealth increase by $217 billion since the election, 60% of Americans live paycheck to paycheck, 25% of seniors live on $15,000 or less and millions cannot afford rent," said U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vermont, referring to Meta/Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Amazon founder Jeff Bezos and Musk, who heads Tesla, X and Starlink.
"Say no to oligarchy," Sanders said.
Musk and Trump have pressed forward with their DOGE efforts highlighting U.S. tax dollars going to foreign aid projects and Social Security databases showing people with age well into their 100s and even 200s and 300s.
On Wednesday, Trump read aloud U.S. spending projects in countries such as Uganda, Moldova, Peru and Serbia and the number of people with lofty ages in the Social Security system database.
"200 to 209 years old: 879 people. 210 to 219 years old: 866 people. 220 to 229 years old: 1,039 people. 240 to 249 years old: 2 people. 1 person that is 360 years old," said Trump, adding that DOGE efforts will see if any benefits are being paid out to those accounts.
Trump and Musk also talked up sending $5,000 'DOGE dividends' to Americans from the savings he is finding in government spending. The checks could also entail sending 20% of DOGE austerity savings to Americans. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on national political efforts to defund Planned Parenthood, involving federal policy debates, presidential figures, and conservative advocacy groups. While health services are mentioned, the core issue revolves around national-level political and social policy rather than local governance, health care delivery, or public safety.

title: Sometimes red, sometimes blue, sometimes neither: State and local police and Trump's ICE raids
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Sometimes red, sometimes blue, sometimes neither: State and local police and Trump's ICE raids

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President Donald Trump's increased immigration raids and promised mass deportations of undocumented migrants are spotlighting the roles local police are — or are not — playing with the crackdowns.Some conservative states and sheriffs are touting new and existing agreements with the U.S. Immigration & Customs Enforcement (ICE) to hold undocumented immigrants accused of other crimes and promised more cooperation with Trump to deal with international gangs, trafficking rings and drug cartels.
Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis announced Feb. 19 that state police agencies were entering into agreements with ICE "to execute functions of immigration enforcement within the state."
"Florida is setting the example for states in combating illegal immigration and working with the Trump Administration to restore the rule of law," DeSantis said. "By allowing our state agents and law enforcement officers to be trained and approved by ICE, Florida will now have more enforcement personnel deputized to assist federal partners. That means deportations can be carried out more efficiently, making our communities safer as illegal aliens are removed."
The Florida Highway Patrol, Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE), Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC), and the Florida State Guard have entered into 287(g) agreements with ICE.
Those deals allow state and local police to administer federal immigration laws.
GANG INFLUXAs of December 2024, ICE had 287(g) agreements with approximately 135 state and local law enforcement agencies nationally, according to the American Immigration Council.
Some of those agreements have been in place for years.
"Nothing has changed in our approach. If someone is being held on local charges and ICE wants to place a 'hold' on them they do. We do participate in the 287(g) program and this has been active for years," said Dan Springer, sheriff in Gallatin County, Montana (which includes Bozeman and Belgrade).
"We have one person designated as a warrant service officer. This allows that detention Officer to serve warrants generated by ICE."
Springer said his deputies will notify ICE of arrestees potentially being in the country illegally if those persons don't have a U.S. Social Security number or valid immigration visa when they are booked for an alleged crime.
"During the booking process, we also ask everyone their place of birth and if it is a foreign country, that also alerts us to notify ICE," Springer said. "ICE is contacted, they review fingerprints, demographics, etc. and they determine citizenship. If determined to be illegal by the ICE agent and they meet certain criteria set forth by ICE, they place an immigration detainer."
Those holds can also apply to immigrants who overstay their visa or have been convicted of serious crimes and face deportation orders.
ICE also has 48 hours to show up at local jails to pick up those with holds after charges are adjudicated or the defendants are bonded out, Springer said.
Trump has designated Mexican cartels and Latin American gangs as terrorist organizations allowing for more U.S. law enforcement, intelligence and military assets to be deployed against those syndicates with a focus on curtailing fentanyl (a potent and dangerous synthetic opioid) and other smuggling in the U.S.
He's also promised to crack down human trafficking rings and has criticized the prior administration for allowing post-pandemic migration waves into the U.S.
Springer said he's seen an influx of gang members in Montana.
"We have been able to classify some as being illegal aliens and some are not," the sheriff said.
Earlier this month, ICE and U.S. Homeland Security agents arrests six alleged members of the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua.
'SANCTUARY PROMISE'Immigration advocates and Democrats worry about Trump's raids sweeping up undocumented migrant workers who are in the U.S. to work and have not committed crimes.
Those migrants often take jobs native-born Americans eschew and are key to sectors such as construction, agriculture and restaurants.
Critics of Trump's promised mass deportations also worry about ICE agents going into churches or schools to make arrests.
Thirteen states — including Oregon, California, Illinois, New York and Colorado as well Utah — have sanctuary laws restricting state and local police from cooperating with ICE.
Another 220 cities and counties also have sanctuary laws protecting undocumented migrants and forbidding local police from cooperating with federal immigration agencies, according for the Center for Immigration Studies.
Those include big cities such as Atlanta, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New Orleans as well as college areas such as Dane County, Wisconsin (Madison); Las Cruces, New Mexico; Athens-Clarke County, Georgia; and Franklin County, Ohio (Columbus).
Illegal immigration was center stage in Athens, Georgia after a Venezuelan man, who had been arrested but not detained in New York and Georgia on other charges, killed nursing student Laken Riley in 2022.
The man, José Antonio Ibarra, was convicted of murder and Congress passed and Trump signed a new law last month requiring federal detention of undocumented immigrants accused of burglary and theft.
Trump has spotlighted other high-profile violent crimes committed by migrants illegally in the U.S. That includes the 2024 killing and sexual assault of 12-year-old Jocelyn Nungaray in Houston; two Venezuelan men illegally in the U.S. were charged with the crime.
Public opinion polls show U.S. voters supporting Trump's deportation push with 59% backing the effort in a CBS News/YouGov poll and 63% in a Napolitan News Service survey this month.
Democrats in sanctuary cities and states have promised to stick by their policies of not working with ICE.
"Our immigrant communities are Oregon communities," said Oregon Gov. Tina Kotek, in a video statement last month. "I will uphold Oregon's sanctuary promise laws."
Portland (Oregon) Police Chief Bob Day said in a statement that a department directive also eschews immigration enforcements.
"I want everyone to feel safe and protected, which is why it is important to understand that the Portland Police Bureau does not engage in immigration enforcement as outlined … Simply put, we have no legal authority to do so," Day said.
U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem and Trump's immigration czar Tom Homan have promised to go after states and local jurisdictions who push back or refuse to help enforce immigration laws. New York City Mayor Eric Adams has promised NYPD cooperation with ICE's removal efforts. That move coincided with the Trump administration dropping corruption charges against the mayor brought by the Biden administration.
'OUR MISSION'Some municipal police departments say immigration enforcements are not within their operations especially with county sheriffs frequently handling jails.
In Omaha, Nebraska, Mayor Jean Stothert, a Republican, and Police Chief Todd Schmaderer, posted a social media video last month saying local police will not inquire about immigration status.
"We don't want anyone to be afraid. If you are the victim of a crime or a witness of crime... the Omaha police will not check your legal status," Stothert said.
Dustin Lensing, police chief in Belgrade, Montana, said his small town department does not have a 287(g) agreement but will provide logistical support to ICE and other federal agencies when requested.
"From a local law enforcement perspective, not a lot has changed in our mission. Our mission at the municipal level is to maintain and ensure the safety of all of our residents and visitors, regardless of immigration status. When a crime or incident occurs, we respond and mitigate the situation," Lensing said.
"At this time, we are not directly contacting ICE whenever we have contact with a potential migrant, as a lot of times, we do not truly know their immigration status (resident, non-resident, visa, green card holder) and we have to be careful to follow laws and restrictions as they apply to profiling persons due to their ethnicity," he continued.
The Belgrade chief has also seen "some increase in gang, drug and labor trafficking issues" and an uptick in federal immigration holds.
"What we are seeing is that some of our arrestees are being held on ICE detainers after we book them into jail on local charges. We do not have involvement in the process since this occurs after our officers have left the facility, but this is not something we have seen much of from ICE in several years," Lensing said.
'WE DON'T ASK FOR IMMIGRATION STATUS'On Maryland's Eastern Shore, Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said a unique setup limits his deputies' involvement with immigration cases.
Gamble said in a number of Maryland counties jails are not administered by local sheriffs. They are run by a separate local corrections department. He said his deputies don't delve into legal status.
"We don't ask for immigration status," Gamble said.
He said when defendants are booked into jail, their fingerprints and information get shared with the FBI and in turn other agencies, including ICE.
"They will see that," Gamble said of whether ICE can tell criminal defendants are potentially undocumented or illegally in the U.S.
While Maryland is one of the most Democratic and progressive states in the union, it does not have sanctuary laws.
Maryland Attorney Anthony Brown, a Democrat, issued fresh immigration guidance in January telling state and local police they "are prohibited from asking about a person's immigration status during regular police functions unless it is relevant to a crime being investigated by that officer." He said "state and local law enforcement officers cannot be prohibited from sharing information about a detainee's citizenship or immigration status with federal immigration officials, but they are not required to do so either."
Brown said more detailed information about a defendant requires a warrant.
Gamble said his agency is often at arms length from those interactions because he doesn't operate the jail.
"We don't know about any of this stuff," Gamble said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on federal immigration enforcement policies under Trump, state-local cooperation with ICE, and political reactions across the U.S., fitting 'National News' as a major federal policy issue. 'Public Safety' is secondary, as the article emphasizes legal/political frameworks over direct safety measures.

title: Anti-Trump protestors rally in Delaware
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Anti-Trump protestors rally in Delaware

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 233
 Words 

 Read News Document

 More than 150 people marched down Main Street in protest against the Trump administration on March 1."I don't know what else to do," organizer Rhona Bergman Perkins said. "I'm a mother and a grandmother. I've been protesting since 1972. I'm not going to leave this to my kids."
The protest was organized by Indivisible Newark First State, a local chapter of the national Indivisible group, which was founded in 2016 to coordinate resistance to the Trump agenda.
Perkins said the Newark chapter was organized in December and plans to continue holding protests and other advocacy events.
"Having faith in goodness, that's what we have to do," she said, adding that Donald Trump is "such a lousy role model for people."
The theme of Saturday's march was protecting democracy. Many protesters held signs condemning Trump and criticizing Elon Musk's involvement in the federal government. Others expressed support for Ukraine, immigrants and diversity initiatives.
The protesters gathered in front of Old College, then marched down the sidewalks of Main Street and Delaware Avenue. They then stood at the corner of South College Avenue and Main Street waiving signs and chanting slogans.
Many motorists honked their horns in support, though there were a few jeers mixed in.
Perkins said it's important to speak out against what Trump is doing to dismantle democracy.
"You think it can't get any worse. That's what we thought in 2017, and then it keeps getting worse," she said.

While the event occurred locally, the content centers on national political issues rather than local governance or community-specific matters.

title: Federal layoffs come home to Oxford
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Federal layoffs come home to Oxford

 March 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 926
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Marine scientist Sierra Hildebrandt had about 30 minutes on Feb. 27 before her government computer and access to her email were revoked at the Cooperative Oxford Laboratory.Hildebrandt had just learned that she'd been terminated from her dream job with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
"I cried," she said about learning the news.
Hildebrandt was one of two NOAA scientists fired from the Oxford lab that day. The two represented a 15% reduction of the lab's total workforce, both state and federal.
"We're already a small lab," Hildebrandt said. She said with the two terminations, there are only two remaining federal employees and one federal government contractor at the Oxford lab who do field work.
Hildebrandt and environmental scientist Jake Shaner, who also was fired from his position at the Oxford lab, were not alone. At least 800 employees across NOAA have lost their jobs since Feb. 27, part of the Trump administration's move to reduce the size of the government. According to the Associated Press, President Donald Trump has called the size of the federal government "bloated."
In an email to The Star Democrat, NOAA public affairs specialist Jasmine Blackwell said she could not discuss "internal personnel and management matters." She said NOAA remains dedicated to its mission of "providing timely information, research and resources that serve the American public and ensure our nation's environmental and economic resilience."
THE IMPACT ON OXFORDAlthough NOAA is known for gathering weather data, the agency does more than that.
At the Cooperative Oxford Laboratory, scientists monitor water quality, tides and the presence of vibrio, which can cause fatal food poisonings, in oyster populations. The lab — which is Oxford's largest employer — works on an array of projects, from oyster restoration to evaluating nature-based solutions like living shorelines.
At the time that Hildebrandt and Shaner were let go, they were implementing a water quality monitoring station in Oxford with another scientist. Shaner said the monitoring station gathers tide data, helping Oxford determine when flooding is likely.
"So that falls off immediately," Shaner said, explaining that leaving one scientist to maintain the station alone would be difficult.
Hildebrandt and Shaner were the only two scientists at the lab working with the Town of Oxford to evaluate the Strand Beach project, a project to create a living shoreline on Oxford's waterfront. Hildebrandt said their job was to understand how the already implemented shoreline was providing coastal protection and additional ecosystem benefits.
Oxford Town Manager Holly Wahl said the loss of Shaner and Hildebrandt from the lab is having an impact on the completion of that project. She said the lab is engrained in the town and surrounding areas.
"When we have the largest employer in town facing terminations, I think that directly will absolutely impact the town from an economic standpoint," Wahl said. "As well as just the economic standpoint of having that innovation and research directly accessible to the town to continue to make improvements to protect property, to protect vital critical resources that we're providing to citizens."
Oxford Commission President Norm Bell said this situation shows Oxford and the Eastern Shore are not isolated from the rest of the country.
"We're really starting to grapple with what do we do longer term so that we can survive as sea levels rise (and) storm water levels rise," he said.
Bell said the work Hildebrandt and Shaner were doing in Oxford was helping the town address those water-related concerns.
THE BIG PICTUREShaner had been working at the Cooperative Oxford Laboratory — which is utilized by NOAA, the Maryland Department of Natural Resources and the U.S. Coast Guard — since 2016. Although Shaner had about nine years under his belt at the lab, eight of them were spent as a state employee. At the time of his termination, Shaner was considered a probationary federal employee.
St. Michaels resident and deep-sea ecologist Andrew Thaler works with NOAA scientists and uses the agency's data. He said that when employees are hired, they are put on a period of probation before they can receive tenure. He said the probation period repeats when someone switches jobs within the federal government.
"So if you get promoted to a management level position, your probation block starts over," he said. "So many people were fired who were senior in the administration."
At the U.S. Department of Agriculture, more than 5,000 probationary employees were temporarily reinstated to their positions via a federal board ruling Wednesday after the employees had been terminated in February. The ruling was determined based on "reasonable grounds" to believe the agency "committed a prohibited personnel practice."
According to the Congressional Research Service, factors that should be taken into account with reductions in force include tenure of employment, military preference, length of service and efficiency or performance ratings. The service states agencies are "generally required" to provide written notice to affected employees 60 days in advance of the date of release.
Hildebrandt said she understands layoffs occur, but she said her and Shaner were well-performing employees.
"I think I wouldn't be as heartbroken if this was done the correct way," she said. "And if both of us were not performing very well in our jobs."
WHAT'S NEXT?"A NOAA job is a dream job for a lot of marine scientists," Thaler said.
Both Hildebrandt and Shaner have filled out forms to volunteer at the lab so they can continue to work on the projects they had been working on in a volunteer capacity.
Shaner said the terminations at the Oxford lab are a resource lost for the community.
"You're losing skilled people that live here, care about the Eastern Shore and the Chesapeake Bay and want to fix problems," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on federal government layoffs under the Trump administration, specifically NOAA scientist terminations, which aligns with national policy decisions. While there is local impact on Oxford, the core subject is a national-level government action affecting a local community.

title: We have abdicated fairness, defending those in need
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
We have abdicated fairness, defending those in need

 March 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 598
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Everything in our heritage, culture, and founding documents celebrates democracy. Article I of the Maryland Constitution proclaims, "That all Government of right originates from the People." The motto of our neighboring state of Virginia is more pointed, "Death to tyrants." However, under Trump our nation seems to have abandoned our position of leadership of democracies in the world, a position we spilled our blood and treasure to win and maintain. With no explanation, discussion, hearings or debate.We now side with Russia, our enemy for decades, a country that threatened to defeat and erase us from the earth. Russia has the largest arsenal of nuclear weapons because they stole the plans for the atomic bomb from us after World War II. They are not hesitant to rattle that saber. On Feb. 24, we voted twice in the United Nations to side with Russia to block a vote to condemn Russia for their unprovoked attack on Ukraine.
Russia was the aggressor, we all saw it happen.
Why have we done this? The only possible explanation is that the president of the United States, Donald J. Trump wants to endear himself to the dictator of Russia Vladimir Putin and now sees himself and our country as beginning a friendship with our sworn enemy Russia. What is this all about? Putin wants to gain Ukrainian territory, then he may march into Europe and attempt to dominate some portion of Europe, probably Poland. Certainly, our NATO allies and I fear the United States will not resist because Donald Trump is now Putin's friend. Putin certainly does not see himself as Donald Trump's friend, but rather Trump is his patsy who will enable Russia to continue their aggression.
I had hoped that President Trump would allay these fears and explain away this foreboding shift in all that we hold dear, but while Trump's speech to Congress was the longest in history there was no effort to explain. There was only more pressure on Ukraine to meet Russia's demands.
What a terrible turn of events, we have abdicated all the principles of fairness and defending those who need our help, trying to make the world a better place and for what? Allowing a self-absorbed, deeply troubled man in the White House to lead us into a relationship with our enemy that will cause great harm to us and to the rest of the world. What are the next steps in this saga? Are we going to side with the Russians in some conflict in Europe? I hope not, but Donald Trump shows no resistance to Putin.
This was reemphasized on Feb. 28 in the White House when Donald Trump and JD Vance told our ally Ukraine and President Volodymyr Zelensky that they are on their own, we the United States will not help them. While Russia continues to advance on Ukraine, President Trump has once again impounded the military aid to Ukraine that Congress appropriated, halted our intelligence assistance to Ukraine, ceased our offensive cyberattacks in response to Russian cyberattacks, cut off any hope of Ukrainian membership in NATO, and called Zelensky a dictator.
Trump even asked us to doubt that Zelensky wants to stop the slaughter of his people in this conflict, that he doesn't want peace badly enough. This is code to Zelensky to agree to Russian demands for territory at the negotiating table. What price has Trump demanded of Putin? Nothing. Trump wants us to reward Russia with membership in the G7.
We all need to strongly resist this course of action and direction for the sake of our country, our democratic heritage, our children and ourselves. Please. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses critical national political events, U.S. foreign policy decisions under Trump, and their implications for democracy and international relations, aligning with 'National News' as the primary topic.

title: DOGE is not first attempt to reduce government
author: DAVID REEL
content:
DOGE is not first attempt to reduce government

 March 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 948
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Hardly a day goes by without continuous updates from Washington, D.C., on plans of and actions by the Trump administration's Department of Government Efficiency, commonly referred to as DOGE.President Trump created DOGE with an executive order on the first day of his second term, affirming it is a key element of his second term agenda. Elon Musk is heading DOGE as a special government employee.
Strong resistance to DOGE started immediately and has not slowed since then. A lawsuit challenging the legality and authority of was filed the same day DOGE was created. Since then, numerous lawsuits have been filed, including those charging DOGE's efforts to access federal agency data violate federal privacy laws.
As of now, questions on how many and exactly how the U.S. Supreme Court will address these lawsuits is anyone's guess.
One question not receiving much attention is the history of and possible lessons learned from past efforts on improving government efficiency and reducing government spending.
The first such effort occurred in 1947 when Congress created the Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, commonly referred to as the Hoover Commission, as former President Herbert Hoover chaired it.
In 1953, Congress approved the Second Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government also commonly referred to as a Hoover Commission, as former President Hoover chaired it.
In 1982, former President Reagan created The President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control, commonly referred to as the Grace Commission, as it was chaired by corporate executive J. Peter Grace, who was an industrialist and CEO of W.R. Grace and Company, a diversified chemical company.
In 1993, former President Clinton launched the National Performance Review (NPR), also commonly referred to as Reinventing Government. Leading it was former Vice President Gore.
Former President Obama established three groups. They were the National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform whose co-chairs were former U.S. Sen. Alan Simpson and former White House Chief of Staff Erskine Bowles; the Domenici-Rivlin Debt Reduction Task Force, chaired by former U.S. Sen. Pete Domenici and Alice Rivlin, former director of the Office of management and Budget and former Federal Reserve Board Vice Chair. The third group, Campaign to Cut Waste, was a large group of Obama administration officials with the stated goal of "hunting down and eliminating misspent tax dollars in every agency and department across the Federal Government."
In a recent article on President Trump's DOGE initiative, John Kamensky, emeritus senior fellow at the IBM Center for The Business of Government, and Mark Abramson, president at Leadership Inc., suggest the following key elements are important for success in federal government spending change efforts:
"Making government work better can gain significant support in Congress as was seen in the first Hoover Commission and the Reinventing Government initiatives. When recommendations need congressional approval, being fast can make a difference. When a reform initiative spans the life of more than one Congress — and there is a chance that either house may flip to the opposing party — then bolder recommendations can be jeopardized. Moving fast also allows more time to focus on implementation. This was a strength of the Reinventing Government initiative.
Reform efforts that try to make government cheaper, such as by eliminating programs or reducing headcount, necessarily involve Congress. Such an emphasis was a stumbling block for the second Hoover Commission and the Grace Commission. Including career civil servants in the work of a reform initiative can increase the success of the "improving program" initiatives since they can gain "buy-in" from the civil service. In contrast, the "eliminating programs" approach has been predominately staffed by individuals outside of government, and civil service "buy-in" was not sought.
Kamensky and Mark Abramson conclude with writing, "At the time of this writing, DOGE has not been operating like any of these past reform efforts, where the need for change is assessed, and recommendations are made for the president and Congress to act upon."
I suggest there is a crucial omission from their observations on the underlying rationale on President Trump's decisions to move quickly and aggressively on the DOGE agenda. Those decisions include bypassing Congress for input on and approval of DOGE goals and operations.
I suggest Trump's thinking reflects a sense of urgency on addressing the steadily increasing national debt. In 2000, that debt was $5.659 trillion, approximately 56% of the country's gross domestic product. By 2010, the national debt was $13.562 trillion, approximately 93% of GDP. It is projected to reach $37 trillion in June of this year.
Despite current and yet to be filed court challenges to DOGE, it remains to be seen what the final decisions will be on those court challenges, especially any rulings handed down by the U.S. Supreme Court.
I suggest any mandates on congressional involvement on DOGE plans and actions may not be relevant going forward, even if the courts rule that a president cannot implement DOGE activities without some levels of congressional input and approval.
The current Republican majorities in Congress have been relatively uninvolved in any efforts to slow down or stop DOGE plans and actions.
If court rulings do limit the scope and authority of DOGE, I suggest Congressional Republicans will move to approve whatever is deemed legally necessary to allow DOGE plans and actions to continue.
As always that could change based on the results of the 2026 midterm election cycle which is already underway.
I further suggest, if Republicans retain control of Congress in the 2026 mid-term elections, they will be even more inclined to approve future DOGE plans and actions at least through the end of Trump's second term.
If the Democrats regain control of the House, the Senate or both, DOGE will be no more than a footnote in the history of Trump's second term. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Trump administration's DOGE initiative, a federal government efficiency effort, and its legal and political implications. It discusses historical precedents for federal reform, court challenges, and congressional dynamics, all of which fall under national-level news. While related to government operations, none of the other topics (e.g., Local Government, Public Safety) match the scale or focus on federal policy.

title: 'Really tense time': Senior centers, Meals on Wheels facing lost funding from Trump's DOGE, potential shutdown
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
'Really tense time': Senior centers, Meals on Wheels facing lost funding from Trump's DOGE, potential shutdown

 March 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News | Section: News 
 
 1295
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Lisa Beedy and Jim Marks are feeling the brunt of the Trump administration's DOGE austerity pushes, a possible federal shutdown and the cancellation of a long-standing federal law that has long funded programs for seniors.And they are bracing for more.
"We have definitely been affected," said Beedy, director of the Belgrade Senior Center. in Montana "It looks like we are not probably going to receive our March contract payment."
Beedy said she was notified by the Rocky Mountain Development Council earlier this month that the Belgrade and other senior centers in Montana might not be receiving monthly installments for meals and other programs for seniors.
The money in question originates with the federal government and filters through the Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services.
In a March 4 letter to senior centers and other providers, Marks, who serves as RMCD program director, said Montana's Aging Services Bureau notified his group "that the state is not able to meet the full March payment to" local agencies.
"This means you should expect no or partial payment from Rocky Aging in March," Marks told the senior centers and other providers.
Marks said the Montana state agency said it might provide state money and other available funds. Officials with the Montana agency have not yet responded to a request for comment.
Beedy said the Belgrade Senior Center has an annual budget of approximately $400,000 with approximately $100,000 coming from federal sources.
"That will definitely leave a hole for us," said Beedy. "That leaves us wondering what the future looks like for us.
The Belgrade center provides Meals on Wheels and congregate meals for local seniors. It also hosts holiday events as well as wellness and other classes. The center is part of the local municipal government and received some of its funding via the city of Belgrade.
Beedy said her center is on track to provide as many as 18,000 meals to local seniors this fiscal year.
She noted that demand has grown with the impacts of inflation and the local area's population growth.
Beedy said community support, via tax-deductible donations, has increased and the center has enough funds to make it through the fiscal year, which ends June 30.
"After that, we're not sure," she said.
Her husband Dave Beedy, who runs the center's kitchen operations is already looking at the best and most economical ways forward.
'A REALLY TENSE TIME'
The future for senior centers and Meals on Wheels food programs across the country could be impacted by President Donald Trump and billionaire Elon Musk's DOGE austerity measures, a potential government shutdown and the uncertain reauthorization of the Older Americans Act.
The GOP-majority U.S. House of Representatives passed a temporary spending bill Tuesday, but the U.S. Senate must also pass the stop-gap plan by the end of day Friday to avoid a government shutdown.
Trump and Republicans need some Democratic senators to help avoid a shutdown.
The administration and Congress will also need to reauthorize the Older Americans Act. The bill was enacted in 1965 and funds federal spending and programs for seniors. The GOP stalled a reauthorization effort in December before Trump took office.
Marks said the federal money stoppage reference in his letter impacts 13 Montana senior centers and meals providers.
He said federal money through the state and his group can make up as much 50% of some Montana senior centers' budgets.
"We are kind of waiting to see what is happening with the shutdown," Marks said.
But even if the shutdown is avoided he is worried about Trump and Musk's DOGE cuts and Congress not reauthorizing the Older Americans Act.
"It's really a tense time cause we don't know what's going to happen," Marks said.
The nonprofit group's regional budget for Montana areas that include Gallatin and Park counties totals $2.8 million with 56% of that coming from the federal government.
Marks said the monthly regional allotments total $120,000 and go to senior centers and other providers. He said those groups are often smaller community and nonprofit groups who have little financial leeway.
"If we lose (funding), we run the risk of our network collapsing," Marks said. The meals programs are aimed at home bound and lower income seniors.
That frustrates Marks.
"Taking food away from older Americans, it's beyond cruelty," he said.
He also worried about larger employment cuts at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services related to aging and Trump and Musk targeting Social Security, Medicaid (which offers public health service to poorer Americans).
Trump and Musk argue their DOGE efforts aim to reduce government waste, bloated government bureaucracies and unnecessary spending.
DOGE efforts have mirrored program cuts in the Heritage Foundation's Project 2025 conservative policy blueprints. Project 2025 included some major overhauls of HHS, which oversees senior programs and funding.
They've pointed to the need to clean up Social Security databases, which include persons with very high ages .
Martin O'Malley, who served as Social Security administrator in the Biden administration, said those database entries do not translate into benefits payments and worries DOGE cuts to staffing and offices could potentially jeopardize Social Security customer service and payments.
WATCHING WITH CONCERN
Across the country in southwest Florida, Erin McLeod, CEO of Senior Friendship Centers Inc., is also worried about the fate of the Older Americans Act (OAA) and funding for meals deliveries to seniors and disabled persons.
"It funds our Meals on Wheels and nutrition programs," McLeod said, of the federal law.
The Florida nonprofit, which also operates senior centers and has educational programs for seniors, has a $20 million annual budget. McLeod said approximately $6.5 million of that comes from the federal government and is key to its meals programs.
"We are delivering 30,000 meals per month," McLeod said of the nonprofit's operations across Charlotte, Lee, Sarasota and DeSoto counties.
Like other senior providers, McLeod is concerned about the potential length and impacts of a federal shutdown as well as DOGE efforts.
Funding cuts or disruptions would result in SFC halting new enrollments in affected programs as higher prices continue to challenge seniors and other Floridians, McLeod said. Like other meals providers and food banks, SFC sees community needs for services still well above pre-pandemic levels
McLeod said private donations can help but they are not likely to be a long-term solution to lost government funding.
She said seniors are also watching, with some trepidation, the fate of Social Security under Trump and Musk's DOGE austerity pushes with concerns about potential staffing cuts and restructuring hurting claims and benefits processing.
"We are really watching Security," she said.
'IMPOSSIBLE CHOICES'
Nationally, Meals on Wheels programs serve more than 250 million meals annually to an estimated 2 million seniors.
For some seniors, delivered meals or meals and events at senior centers are their only social interactions.
Senior centers and meal providers have also reported increased demand with high post-pandemic inflation, including for food prices and items such as eggs.
Breyana Franklin, external relations manager for Meals on Wheels America, worries about a government shutdown now or the next time the Trump administration and Congress face budgetary crossroads.
"We're coming up on the March 14 expiration of the current FY 2025 appropriations continuing resolution. If that expires without action, the government will shut down, and a shutdown for any considerable length of time could lead to a delay in federal funding reimbursements for meals and services delivered," said
"This would force Meals on Wheels providers to make near impossible choices such as suspending meal services, initiating or expanding waiting lists for meals, reducing the number of meals or delivery days or even closing their doors altogether."
She's also worried about the future of the OAA.
"We are deeply disappointed that the reauthorization of the Older Americans Act (OAA) has not yet happened despite it lapsing several months ago," Franklin said.
"This serves as a stark reminder that the needs of our nation's older adults do not receive the attention they deserve. It is crucial to not only reauthorize the OAA but also to increase funding for this vital legislation," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on federal funding cuts to senior programs due to Trump's DOGE policies and potential government shutdowns, which are national political and economic issues. While it touches on public safety and health impacts, the core subject is federal policy and its nationwide implications, aligning most closely with 'National News.'

title: Americans must speak out
author: Staff Writer
content:
Americans must speak out

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last Saturday night, the Trump regime used ICE to illegally detain Mahmoud Khalil (a green card holder) without warrant or charge, to try to arrest his pregnant wife and to kidnap Khalil to an undisclosed location it refused to share with his family. This illegal, terrorizing behavior would be expected from a dictatorship but not from our government.Any doubt as to the in terrorem role ICE would serve for the Trump regime is quickly vanishing. ICE is for Trump what the Gestapo was for Hitler, a force to stifle opposition with threats, force and torture.
Khalil has no criminal record. All he did was to exercise his Constitutional rights by organizing peaceful protests at Columbia that opposed continued funding for Netanyahu as Netanyahu committed well-documented war crimes against Palestinians.
When confronted, ICE first claimed Khalil's visa was being revoked but, when informed that he has a green card, changed its story to state his green card was being revoked. However, the decision to revoke a green card can only be made by an immigration judge after the government procures a warrant, makes a legal arrest, files charges, tries the person, convicts the person and allows that person to exhaust all appeals.
Instead of allowing the due process our Constitution affords every person – citizen or not – the Trump regime executed an autocratic move to stifle dissent and disappear a dissenter that resembles the manner in which Putin deals with dissenters in Russia. This amounts to government terrorism and follows the Trump regime's open repression of student activism and political speech, in this instance criticism of Israel and Netanyahu. Thus, the Trump regime has shown it will use immigration to suppress free speech.
If Columbia secretly colluded with the Trump regime in the arrest, it may be a result of the regime's recent cancellation of $400 million in grants and contracts. Trump proved that he is willing to use extortion to achieve personal goals when threatened to withhold funding to force Ukraine to announce an investigation of Biden, so it is not surprising that Trump would use extortion to force colleges to kowtow to his wishes to silence dissent by wrongfully withholding the funds they are entitled to receive, but it is chilling.
Americans must speak out against this brutal and illegal conduct.
JACK L. WUERKER
Tilghman

title: Rep. Jamie Raskin comes to Cambridge for town hall
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Rep. Jamie Raskin comes to Cambridge for town hall

 March 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 571
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Energy was high as Eastern Shore residents packed the gymnasium at Mace's Lane Middle School Saturday for Cambridge Indivisible and Eastern Shore Indivisible's town hall event with Maryland U.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Md.)."I know I was not your first choice," Raskin said over cheers from the crowd. "I heard your congressman couldn't quite squeeze you in today."
Raskin represents most of Montgomery County and part of Prince George's County. Cambridge Indivisible Co-Founder and Co-Chair Michelle Fowle said the organization invited Maryland U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) — who represents the Eastern Shore and lives in Cambridge — but Harris didn't respond.
"We made it super easy for him to be here, and he didn't even have the decency to formally decline," Fowle said. "He just completely ignores us and just tells everybody that we're paid $40 an hour and bused in."
Although Harris wasn't at the Cambridge Indivisible event Saturday, he is holding a telephone hall for residents on Tuesday, March 25. Those who would like to attend the event, which will be from 5:30 to 6:30 p.m., can listen in by calling 833-380-0671 or can stream the event at harris.house.gov/live.
During the town hall Saturday, Raskin expressed concerns with the Republican Party's priorities.
He brought up recent actions taken by President Donald Trump and the the Department of Government Efficiency. He said he is trying to "stop this savage assault on American democracy."
"They're not opponents of corruption," Raskin said. "They're agents of corruption."
When it came to the question and answer portion of the town hall, residents asked what could be done in response to the Trump administration's actions.
Many made a point to mention they were not paid to be there, referencing Harris' words following a rally Cambridge Indivisible organized in opposition to the congressman March 13. Harris told members of the media he didn't believe many of the people at the rally were his constituents, adding that he believed they were paid protesters "brought in by buses."
Commenting on the Saturday town hall, Harris said in a statement Monday that it's "ironic" that "ultra-radical leftist" Raskin is "suddenly pretending to care about our farmers, watermen and people on the Eastern Shore after four years of voting for reckless Biden administration policies and radical environmental regulations — which almost crushed our Eastern Shore economy."
"If these protests weren't being paid for and influenced by radical Democrat activists, Jaime Raskin would have stayed on the western shore — right where he and his radical policies belong," Harris said.
Throughout the event Saturday, volunteers were available with smart phones to capture residents' stories.
"Andy Harris can ignore our emails, he can dodge our phone calls and he can refuse to hold a town hall," Cambridge Indivisible Co-Founder and Co-Chair Andy Fowle said. "But he cannot erase our stories."
Retired East New Market resident Roscoe Handy, who attended the event, said he has concerns about the fate of Social Security, Medicare and the U.S. Department of Education. He said Harris needs to hear from his constituents and put a face to their name.
"I didn't necessarily vote for him. However, I'm in his district," said Handy, a Democrat.
At the end of the event, Raskin was asked if he has plans to run for president in the next U.S. presidential election.
"I will do whatever is necessary for us to save our democracy," he said in response as applause and cheers filled the room.
This report has been updated to include comment from Andy Harris. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Loss of federal funds could leave migrant children in the lurch
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Loss of federal funds could leave migrant children in the lurch

 April 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 803
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Trump administration is moving ahead with plans to end a contract that pays for the legal representation of children navigating immigration court cases after entering the country without parents or guardians.That decision could have outsize impacts in Maryland, where a disproportionate share of unaccompanied immigrant children have landed in recent years, often fleeing violence, sexual abuse, and neglect.
The state's nonprofit legal aid groups are now grappling with the prospect of young clients facing the courts alone, raising the risk that children miss hearings, lose connections to service providers, and receive deportation orders.
Estefani Flores Portillo, a social services coordinator with the Amica Center for Immigrant Rights, says the loss of funding could also leave more than a thousand clients across Maryland — most in their teens — to balance fending for themselves in immigration court with the day-to-day challenges of acclimating to a new country.
"Outside of their legal case, they also have other priorities," she said. Most of her clients are enrolled in school, some hold down jobs to cover basic living expenses, and many require therapy to process traumas inflicted both in their home countries and during their journeys to the U.S.
Burdened with those competing pressures, she added, "it would be hard for them to focus on the legal case" without the assistance of an attorney.
On March 21, the administration notified nonprofit legal aid groups providing representation for unaccompanied immigrant children that it would terminate the contract that funds their work. Those legal aid groups collectively represent more than 26,000 children with cases before immigration courts across the country, and they provide consultations and referrals to thousands more each year.
The withdrawal of federal support for legal representation of immigrant children comes as immigration courts struggle to manage a staggering backlog of cases, including more than 50,000 in Maryland alone as of February 2025.
Maryland has received among the largest numbers of unaccompanied immigrant children in the past decade relative to other states.
Data from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) indicates that nearly 40,000 unaccompanied immigrant children have been released to sponsors — either family members or volunteers — in Maryland since 2014. A majority of those children arrived after 2020, primarily from Central America.
Only Texas, California, Florida and New York received more unaccompanied immigrant children in the same period.
Roughly 13,000 of those children landed in Prince George's County alone, though even some corners of rural Maryland have seen hundreds of new arrivals in the past five years.
Even with legal representation, unaccompanied children often spend years awaiting the resolution of their case, both because of the burden on immigration courts and asylum offices and because of the limited number of visas available each year.
"Kids don't want to think about these things longer than they have to," said Caroline Hodge, a supervising attorney with the Amica Center. The immigration court system is difficult enough for attorneys to navigate, she added, and children hardly stand a chance on their own.
Though the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act requires HHS to provide legal counsel to all children in its care "to the greatest extent possible," thousands of children with open immigration cases already lack representation.
That shortfall is driven in part by a nationwide shortage of immigration attorneys prepared to work with juvenile clients. Until this month, federal dollars also helped nonprofits like the Amica Center train attorneys willing to volunteer their time to represent children in immigration court. The end of the federal contract supporting her organization's work, Hodge said, also means her team will no longer be able to provide that training.
Immigration court data collected by the U.S. Department of Justice between 2004 and 2016 suggests that roughly 60 percent of children with cases in a Maryland immigration court had legal representation during that period. The same data indicates that while nearly all children with attorneys appeared in court for a final decision in their case, only a third of those without attorneys did so.
"The idea of going to court is so terrifying for a child," Hodge said, "and people without information, without representation, will definitely feel more fearful to engage."
The Trump administration has already signaled its interest in following through on deportation orders issued for children who fail to appear for immigration court hearings.
Maryland's Department of Human Services, which houses the state's Office for Refugees and Asylees, has so far avoided commenting on the end of federal funding for immigrant children's legal representation. A department spokesperson referred CNS to its federal counterpart, HHS, for comment, though that agency likewise did not immediately respond to inquiries about the expected outcomes of the decision.
Meanwhile, legal aid groups told Capital News Service that some attorneys fear that continuing to offer pro bono legal assistance to immigrants will make them targets, citing the White House's recent efforts to punish law firms deemed hostile to the administration. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a federal policy decision (Trump administration ending legal aid funding for immigrant children) with national implications, including impacts on Maryland and broader immigration court systems. While race/diversity aspects are present, the core issue is a major national policy shift affecting multiple states.

title: Jeffrey Epstein's 'little black book' sold at auction house
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content:
Jeffrey Epstein's 'little black book' sold at auction house

 April 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 479
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A "little black book" of names and contact information that once belonged to deceased sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein was sold for $10,000 at Alexander Historical Auctions in Elkton on Wednesday evening.Although the estimated value for Epstein's book ranged from $20,000 to $30,000, at Alexander Historical Auctions in Elkton on Wednesday, the 64 pages filled with nearly 400 printed names and contacts of high-profile individuals were acquired for $10,000, holding the same bidding price throughout the day, far below the estimated value.
Epstein's phone book was up for auction in August 2024 with a starting bid of $35,000 and had previously drawn offers up to $100,000, but the offers were rejected by the owner, who hoped a researcher would purchase the relic to uncover the sex offender's ties to governments, according to auctioneer Bill Panagopulos. Auctioneers assured bidders that their identities are not revealed.
"We tried to sell it last auction with a big reserve, and I called it … radioactive," Panagopulos said about Epstein's notebook moments before the auction started Wednesday morning. "There are people who won't even touch it, right?"
The book went on quite a journey before the Elkton-based auctioneer acquired the black plastic Gestetner-bound contact log. Denise Ondayko, a musician from the East Village, claims she found the book on a Manhattan sidewalk in the 1990s, according to Business Insider. After Epstein's death in 2019, she put it up for sale on eBay.
Christopher Helali — the International Secretary for the American Communist Party, who was working as an independent reporter — purchased it for a mere $425, according to the New York Post.
"Nobody believes it's real. He buys it for nothing, and he is more interested in the story than in the value of the piece," Panagopulos said, adding that Helali had Business Insider bring in a forensic expert to authenticate the book.
The 4.5-inch-by-5.25 inch book contains 386 printed entries varying in length from one or two lines to 10 or 15 lines each. It has two additional entries written in what looks like Epstein's handwriting, but is too small to tell, according to the auction item description. There are five highlighted names who are all well recognized financial and industrial professionals, including current president Donald Trump.
The FBI discovered a different "little black book" of Epstein's circa 2004, and used it in legal proceedings throughout his various for soliciting prostitution from minors and federal sex trafficking. FBI investigations started in 2005, with a pause for several years in between, and ended in 2019 when the criminal was found dead in his jail cell, which investigators declared a suicide, according to the Associated Press.
The earlier book — which was just sold at auction — was not considered important to the investigation when it was discovered. The two volumes combined hold 1,731 names, 221 of which are in the earlier book, but not the 2004 version, according to Business Insider. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
